In his Christmas message, Cardinal Murphy-O'Connor called for 2005 to be a year of "making history" by campaigning to eradicate poverty, rather than perpetuating a cycle of conflict. His remarks serve as a powerful reminder of the devastating human cost of war and the urgent need for more effective, compassionate, and sustainable solutions to global challenges.

original: British stars denied major oscars british hopes of winning major oscars were dashed as uk stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, mike leigh's vera drake failed to take the director or screenplay awards and there was no prize for star imelda staunton. Kate winslet also lost to best actress hilary swank, while clive owen and sophie okonedo failed to win best supporting actor awards. The uk's andrea arnold won the short film award for her gritty drama wasp. Arnold, who presented children's television shows number 73 and motormouth in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. Wasp tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, beating films by fellow uk nominees gary mckendry and ashvin kumar.
polished: British stars' high hopes of winning major Oscars were left in tatters as UK stars failed to secure acting and directing prizes, despite receiving three nominations. Mike Leigh's 'Vera Drake' failed to take home the director or screenplay awards, and Imelda Staunton was overlooked for her outstanding performance. Kate Winslet lost to Hilary Swank in the best actress category, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okenedo were unable to claim the best supporting actor awards. However, Andrea Arnold, the director of 'Wasp', a gritty drama that tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, made it a night to remember by winning the short film award. The former children's television show presenter, Arnold, described the experience as "totally overwhelming". 'Wasp' is a powerful film that beat out fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar, and its emotional portrayal of a single mother's struggles resonated with the Academy.

original: Halloween writer debra hill dies screenwriter and producer debra hill, best known for her work on the 70s horror classic halloween, has died in los angeles aged 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred jamie lee curtis as a babysitter terrorised by a psychopath. Directed by john carpenter, it made over $60m (£31.3m) worldwide - a record for independent film at that time. Hill also worked with carpenter on escape from new york and the fog. Born in new jersey, hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 70s that were more commonly taken by men.
polished: Debra Hill, the renowned screenwriter and producer, best known for her work on the 1978 horror classic "Halloween," has passed away at the age of 54 in Los Angeles. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the iconic film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter tormented by a psychopath, under the direction of John Carpenter. The film's massive success, which grossed over $60 million worldwide, was a record-breaking achievement for an independent film at the time. Hill's impressive body of work also includes collaborations with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and steadily worked her way up the ranks, eventually becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before partnering with Carpenter. Throughout her illustrious career, Hill was widely regarded as a trailblazing woman in the film industry, taking on roles in the 1970s that were often reserved for her male counterparts.

original: Broadband fuels online expression fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in britain regularly upload content and have personal sites, according to a report by uk think-tank demos. It said that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the uk have broadband and that number is growing fast. The demos report looked at the impact of broadband on people's net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged on to the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the web. More significantly, argues the report, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.
polished: According to research, the widespread availability of broadband internet access is fuelling an explosion in online self-expression, with a quarter of British broadband users regularly uploading content and maintaining personal websites. The report by UK think-tank Demos highlights that having an always-on, fast connection is revolutionizing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and this figure is growing rapidly. The study examined the impact of broadband on people's online habits and found that over half of those with broadband log on to the web before breakfast. Moreover, one in five respondents admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse the internet, underscoring the notion that broadband is empowering people to take a more proactive role online.

original: Yukos heading back to us courts russian oil and gas company yukos is due in a us court on thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is in the process of being broken up by russian authorities in order to pay a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the us, hoping to use international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, yuganskneftegas. The unit was however sold for $9.4bn to state oil firm rosneft but only after the state auction had been disrupted. Yukos lawyers now say the auction violated us bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to go after any company that buys its assets, using all and every legal means.
polished: Yukos, the Russian oil and gas company, is set to face a US court on Thursday as it continues its fight for survival. The firm is currently being dismantled by Russian authorities to settle a $27 billion tax bill. Yukos has filed for bankruptcy in the US, seeking to exploit international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. However, the unit was sold for $9.4 billion to state-owned oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction was disrupted. Yukos' lawyers now claim that the auction violated US bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any entity that acquires its assets, using all legal means at their disposal.

original: Voters flock to blog awards site voting is under way for the annual bloggies which recognise the best web blogs - online spaces where people publish their thoughts - of the year. Nominations were announced on sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that the website was temporarily closed because of too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, from the top regional blog, to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a huge year, with a top us dictionary naming "blog" word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and says that more than 12,000 are added daily. A blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to us research think-tank pew internet and american life, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.
polished: Voters are flocking to the blog awards website, where the annual Bloggies ceremony is underway, recognizing the best online weblogs that showcase the year's most thought-provoking and engaging content. The nominations were announced on Sunday, but the heavy traffic to the official site caused the website to temporarily shut down due to the overwhelming number of visitors. This year, weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. The blogosphere has had a remarkable year, with the term "blog" being named as the Word of the Year in 2004 by a leading dictionary. According to Technorati, a prominent blog search engine, there are approximately six million blogs online, with over 12,000 new ones being added daily. Interestingly, a new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, according to research by the Pew Internet and American Life project. However, only less than 40% of these blogs are updated at least once every two months, highlighting the dynamic nature of this ever-evolving online landscape.

original: Chinese dam firm 'defies beijing' the china three gorges project corp is refusing to obey a government order to stop construction of one of its giant dams, the chinese state press has said. The builder of the three gorges dam is continuing work on the sister xiluodu dam, said the beijing news. The xiluodu dam is one of 30 such large-scale construction projects called to a halt because of a lack of proper environmental checks. The beijing news said the company may instead choose to pay a fine. The firm has also ignored orders to stop construction at two of its other projects - the three gorges underground power plant and the three gorges project electrical power supply plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by china's state environmental protection agency (sepa) for having not carried out mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with its shutdown order.
polished: Despite defying a government directive, the Chinese company, Beijing Three Gorges Project Corp, is continuing construction on its Xiluodu Dam, according to a report by the Chinese State Press. The company is ignoring a government order to halt construction on one of its massive projects, which is part of a larger group of 30 large-scale construction projects ordered to be suspended due to inadequate environmental assessments. The Beijing News reported that the company may instead opt to pay a fine for non-compliance. Additionally, the firm has disregarded orders to cease construction at two other projects, the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. As of now, only 22 of the 30 projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for failing to conduct mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with the shutdown order.

original: Man city 0-2 man utd manchester united reduced chelsea's premiership lead to nine points after a scrappy victory over manchester city. Wayne rooney met gary neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which went in via a deflection off richard dunne, to put united ahead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate dunne hooked a volley over david james' head and into his own net. Steve mcmanaman wasted city's best chance when he shot wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes united had looked unlikely to earn the win they needed to maintain any chance of catching chelsea in the title race. Their approach play was more laboured than patient and they managed to fashion just one chance - a paul scholes header over the bar.
polished: Manchester United's 0-2 defeat to Manchester City was a scrappy and hard-fought victory for the Red Devils, as they claimed nine points in the Premier League table. Wayne Rooney's clinical finish was the highlight of the match, as he met Gary Neville's cross with a low shot that deflected off Richard Dunne and found the back of the net. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne's volley over David James' head and into his own net brought the game back to 1-2. Steve McManaman had Manchester City's best chance when he shot wide from just three yards out in the first half. Despite a laboured approach, United managed to create just one chance, a Paul Scholes header that sailed over the bar. The Red Devils' performance in the opening 45 minutes was far from convincing, but they managed to keep the pressure on Chelsea and maintain any hope of catching their opponents in the title race.

original: Wales 'must learn health lessons' the new health minister for wales says there are lessons to learn from england in tackling waiting lists. Dr brian gibbons, on his first full day in the job after jane hutt was sacked, admitted "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. But both plaid cymru and the liberal democrats said dr gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile ms hutt defended her record, saying waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda. Dr gibbons, who was a gp in blaengwynfi, in the upper afan valley, before becoming am for aberavon, said nhs staff wanted a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform". One of the biggest problems which had faced ms hutt during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in wales.
polished:
Wales Must Draw Health Lessons from England, Says New Health Minister

As Wales' new Health Minister, Dr. Brian Gibbons, began his tenure, he acknowledged that there are valuable lessons to be learned from England's approach to tackling waiting lists. On his first full day in office, following the departure of Jane Hutt, Dr. Gibbons described the challenges ahead as "big," but emphasized that the fundamentals were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats called for a policy shift, urging Dr. Gibbons to adopt a new strategy. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, arguing that waiting times and lists comprised only a small fraction – 10% – of the broader health agenda.

original: Ferguson hails man utd's resolve manchester united's alex ferguson has praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 win at aston villa. "that was our hardest away game of the season and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the old trafford boss. "we showed lots of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. "i look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while arsenal and chelsea have yet to come and villa may have some players back when they do." ferguson also hailed senior stars ryan giggs and roy keane, who came off the bench for the injured john o'shea. "roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield which we needed and which no other player has got.
polished: Sir Alex Ferguson has lauded the Manchester United players for their resilient performance in their 1-0 win against Aston Villa, describing it as the team's most challenging away game of the season. 'That was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end, with lots of good passing,' Ferguson said. 'We showed a lot of character and guts and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come and Aston Villa may have some players back when they do.' Ferguson also praised senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. 'Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield, which no other player has got.'

original: Singer's film to show at festival a documentary which takes a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer george michael will be shown at this year's berlin film festival. A different story will screen in the panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 february. It features the singer talking about both his career and his personal life, from his days in wham! through to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 february. Director southan morris and executive producer andy stephens will also attend the festival. The 93 minute film will see michael discussing his early days in wham! along with his later career, including his legal battles with record label sony and his stance against the iraq war and american politics.
polished: The upcoming Berlin Film Festival will feature a documentary about the life of chart-topping singer George Michael, which offers a candid look at his remarkable career and personal life. The documentary, which will be screened in the Panorama section of the festival, will showcase Michael discussing his early days in Wham! and his later career, including his legal battles with Sony and his stance on the Iraq War and American politics. The 93-minute film will be introduced by George Michael himself on February 16. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also be in attendance at the festival. The documentary will run from February 10-20, offering a unique glimpse into the life and career of this iconic singer.

original: Downloads enter us singles chart digital music downloads are being included in the main us singles chart for the first time. Billboard's hot 100 chart now incorporates data from sales of music downloads, previously only assigned to a separate download chart. Green day's boulevard of broken dreams is currently number two in billboard's pop chart, and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be incorporated into the uk singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the us are already used to compile billboard's hot digital sales chart. They will now be tallied with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new hot 100 chart. Its second new chart - the pop 100 - also combines airplay, digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to us radio stations which play chart music.

The incorporation of download sales into the US singles chart is expected to occur later this year. Digital sales in the US are already used to compile Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with sales of physical singles and airplay information to make up its new Hot 100 chart. The second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay, digital, and physical sales, but confines its airplay data to US radio stations that play chart music.

original: Anti-spam laws bite spammer hard the net's self-declared spam king is seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott richter, the man behind optinrealbig.com and billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits had forced the company into chapter 11. Optinrealbig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for chapter 11 would help it try to resolve its legal problems but still keep trading. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog spamhaus, optinrealbig was sued in december 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by microsoft and new york attorney general eliot spitzer who alleged that mr richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.
polished: Optinrealbig.com, the self-proclaimed spam king, is seeking bankruptcy protection as the company, led by Scott Richter, faces significant financial difficulties. The company, which has been involved in several legal battles, including a notable lawsuit against Microsoft, is now seeking to restructure its debt through a chapter 11 bankruptcy filing. This move is seen as a strategic attempt to resolve the company's legal issues while still allowing it to continue operating. As the third-largest spammer in the world, according to the junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, Optinrealbig has faced numerous legal challenges. In 2003, the company was sued by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Scott Richter and his associates sent billions of spam messages to 514 compromised email addresses in 35 countries. The lawsuit was a result of Optinrealbig's alleged violation of anti-spam laws, which led to a significant backlash from the online community.

original: Arnesen denies rift with santini tottenham sporting director frank arnesen has denied that coach jacques santini resigned because of a clash of personalities at white hart lane. There had been newspaper speculation that santini had felt undermined by arnesen's role at the club. "it is absolutely not true," arnesen told bbc radio five live. "there is only one thing that made him resign and that is his own personal problems. "he has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely for himself." arnesen said he was unable to throw any light onto the problems that caused santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But i trust him in that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.
polished: Arnesen has denied any rift with Santini, Tottenham's sporting director, and has dismissed reports that he resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. According to Arnesen, the reports are 'absolutely not true', and he has spoken with Santini recently, who attributed his departure to his own personal problems. 'It's not true,' Arnesen told BBC Radio 5 Live. 'There's only one thing that made him resign, and that's his own personal problems.' Arnesen refused to comment on the specific issues that led to Santini's departure after just 13 games in charge. He did, however, acknowledge that Santini had never publicly disclosed the reasons behind his decision, but emphasized that he respected the situation. 'I think we should respect it,' Arnesen said.

original: Ireland surge past scots ireland maintained their six nations grand slam ambitions with an impressive victory over scotland at murrayfield. Hugo southwell's try gave the scots an early 8-0 lead but scores from locks malcolm o'kelly and paul o'connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing denis hickie and third penalty from ronan o'gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon petrie scored a second try for scotland but late scores from john hayes and gavin duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, eddie o'sullivan' side can now look forward to welcoming england to lansdowne road in a fortnight. Scotland will try to give their coach matt williams a first six nations victory when italy come to edinburgh, but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.

A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-fought away wins, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will strive to give their coach Matt Williams a first Six Nations victory when Italy comes to Edinburgh, but they struggled to turn pressure into points.

original: Economy focus for election battle britain's economic future will be at the heart of labour's poll campaign, chancellor gordon brown has said. He was speaking after cabinet members held their last meeting at no 10 before the expected election announcement. He said voters would recognise that labour had brought stability and growth, and would continue to do so. Meanwhile the tories outlined their plans to tackle "yob culture" and the lib dems gave more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier the archbishop of canterbury wrote to all three parties urging them not to fight the election by exploiting people's fears. In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

In an open letter, he called on them not to turn the election into a competition about who can most effectively frighten voters about these issues.

original: Brizzel to run aaa's in sheffield ballymena sprinter paul brizzel will be among eight of ireland's european indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's aaa's championships. Us-based alistair cragg and mark carroll are the only irish athletes selected so far for the europeans who will not run in sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the british trials. In-form james mcilroy will hope to confirm his place in the british team for madrid by winning the 800m title. Mcilroy has been in tremendous form on the european circuit in recent weeks. Carroll is ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking at the moment with cragg occupying top spot.

original: Robinson wants dual code success england rugby union captain jason robinson has targeted dual code success over australia on saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, leads england against australia at twickenham at 1430 gmt. And at 1815 gmt, great britain's rugby league team take on australia in the final of the tri-nations tournament. "beating the aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said robinson. England have the chance to seal their third autumn international victory after successive wins over canada and south africa, as well as gaining revenge for june's 51-15 hammering by the wallabies. Meanwhile, great britain could end 34 years of failure against australia with victory at elland road.
polished: England's dual-code star, Jason Robinson, has set his sights on dual-code success against Australia on Saturday. Beating the Australians in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league, and England have the chance to put an end to 34 years of failure against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

original: Warning over tsunami aid website net users are being told to avoid a scam website that claims to collect cash on behalf of tsunami victims. The site looks plausible because it uses an old version of the official disasters emergency committee webpage. However, dec has no connection with the fake site and says it has contacted the police about it. The site is just the latest in a long list of scams that try to cash in on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The link to the website is contained in a spam e-mail that is currently circulating. The message's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal" and its text bears all the poor grammar and bad spelling that characterises many other phishing attempts.

This is just the latest in a long list of scams that attempt to capitalize on the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. Be wary of such scams and do not fall prey to their fraudulent schemes.

original: Iraq to invite phone licence bids iraq is to invite bids for two telephone licences, saying it wants to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. Bids have been invited from local, arab and foreign companies, iraq's ministry of communications said. The winner will work in partnership with the iraqi telecommunications and post company (itpc). The firms will install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax and internet services. The ministry said that it wanted to increase iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." it also hopes to develop a "highly visible and changeable telecommunication sector". Details of the bidding and tender process will be published on the ministry's website on 9 february. It also is planning a road-show for investors in amman, jordan.
polished: Iraq invites phone licence bids from local, Arab and foreign companies to significantly boost nationwide coverage over the next decade. The ministry of communications has invited bids for two telephone licences, with the goal of increasing Iraq's very low telephone service penetration rate from approximately 4.5% to around 25% within the next 10 years. The successful bidder will partner with the Iraqi telecommunications and post company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, providing voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry aims to develop a highly visible and changeable telecommunications sector, with a road-show for investors scheduled in Amman, Jordan. The tender details will be published on the ministry's website on February 9. This move is expected to boost the country's telecommunications sector and enhance its global connectivity.

original: More women turn to net security older people and women are increasingly taking charge of protecting home computers against malicious net attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women buying programs to protect pcs from virus, spam and spyware attacks rose by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, for net security firm preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diversity of surfers. It is thought that 40% of those buying home net security programs are retired. For the last three years, that has gone up by an average of 13.2%. But more retired women (53%) were buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotype and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband net connections can pose to surfers.
polished: According to a two-year study, women are increasingly taking charge of protecting their home computers from malicious internet attacks, with the number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks rising by 11.2% each year between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted by a leading internet security firm, reveals that security messages are reaching a diverse range of internet users. It is believed that 40% of those purchasing home network security software are retired individuals, a figure that has increased by an average of 13.2% over the past three years. Moreover, more retired women (53%) are buying security software than retired men, reflecting the shifting demographics and growing awareness of the greater risks that high-speed broadband internet connections pose to internet users.

original: Podcasts mark rise of diy radio an apple ipod or other digital music players can hold anything up to 10,000 songs, which is a lot of space to fill. But more and more ipod owners are filling that space with audio content created by an unpredictable assortment of producers. It is called "podcasting" and its strongest proponent is former mtv host and vj (video jockey) adam curry. Podcasting takes its name from the apple ipod, although you do not need an ipod to create one or to listen to a podcast. A podcast is basically an internet-based radio show which podcasters create, usually in the comfort of their own home. They need only a microphone, a pc, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet and others can download and listen to them, all for free.
polished: Podcasting has revolutionized the way people consume digital music, allowing individuals to store up to 10,000 songs on their Apple iPod or other digital music players. However, podcasting has also led to an explosion of creative content, with an unpredictable array of producers creating audio content. The term "podcasting" originated from the Apple iPod, although it is not necessary to own one to create or listen to a podcast. Essentially, a podcast is an internet-based radio show, where podcasters can produce their own shows from the comfort of their own homes. All they require is a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. They then upload their shows to the internet, making them accessible for free download and listening by others.

original: Levy takes whitbread novel prize orange prize winner andrea levy has seen her book small island win the whitbread novel of the year award. She is now favourite to win the overall prize after beating booker winner alan hollinghurst's the line of beauty. Geraldine mccaughrean has picked up the children's fiction award for the third time for not the end of the world. All the category winners go through to compete for the whitbread book of the year title, which carries with it a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges including sir trevor mcdonald, actor hugh grant and writer joanne harris will meet up on 25 january to decide the overall winner, with the announcement being made later that evening. original: Yukos seeks court action on sale yukos will return to a us court on wednesday to seek sanctions against baikal finance group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue baikal and others involved in the sale of yuganskneftegas for $20bn in damages. original: Sun offers processing by the hour sun microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service which will allow customers requiring huge computing power to rent it by the hour. Sun grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by sun. So-called grid computing is the latest buzz phrase in a company which believes that computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likened grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities such as electricity and water have developed, said sun's chief operating officer jonathan schwartz. "why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked in a webcast launching sun's quarterly network computing event in california.
polished: Sun Microsystems has introduced a revolutionary pay-as-you-go service that empowers customers to harness the power of computing resources on a flexible, on-demand basis. This innovative offering, known as grid computing, allows users to rent computing power and storage capacity on a per-hour basis, with prices starting at just $1.53 per hour. The company likens grid computing to the development of electricity, suggesting that computing capacity is as essential a commodity as hardware and software. According to Sun's Chief Operating Officer, Jonathan Schwartz, "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California, highlighting the convenience and cost-effectiveness of the service.

original: Jamieson issues warning to bigots scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she wants to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy jamieson said exclusion orders are one of a series of measures being considered in the scottish executive campaign against sectarianism. She praised celtic and rangers for their work in tackling the problem. However, the minister said stopping sectarian abuse associated with old firm matches is a key objective. Ms jamieson was speaking ahead of the third round scottish cup clash between the glasgow clubs at parkhead on sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the executive. Last week ms jamieson and first minister jack mcconnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

Jamieson emphasized that stopping the sectarian abuse linked to historic club rivalries is a key objective. Speaking ahead of the third Scottish Cup clash between Glasgow clubs at Hampden Park on Sunday, Jamieson reiterated the Scottish Government's commitment to tackling the problem. The sectarianism, which has been a significant challenge for the executive, has been a long-standing issue, with sections of both clubs' support bases being a focal point. Last week, Jamieson and First Minister Nicola Sturgeon met with representatives from both clubs to discuss the matter in more detail.

original: Us woman sues over cartridges a us woman is suing hewlett packard (hp), saying its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. But the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty.

original: Tories outlining policing plans local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under plans unveiled by the conservatives. Here's a guide to the plan: people coming to live and work in britain from outside the eu. If they plan to stay six months or more and are from a country with lots of tb, they would have to have a chest x-ray and further tests if appropriate. polished: At a glance, the UK opposition has unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan  individuals coming to live and work in the UK from outside the EU will be subject to health checks if they plan to stay six months or more. Those from countries with a high incidence of TB will be required to undergo a chest X-ray and further tests if deemed necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union who plan to stay a year or more will be required to undergo a comprehensive medical examination, including tests for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive test for TB would automatically result in visa applications being rejected. All other conditions will be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

original: New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by cutting drink-drive limits by a third, a report says. University college london research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives a year. The findings are being published by the parliamentary advisory council for transport safety as mps are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, carried out by transport expert professor richard allsop, says cutting the limit would also lead to 230 fewer serious injuries on the uk's roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m a year. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 department of transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives a year.
polished: A groundbreaking report from University College London reveals that slashing the drink-drive limit by a third could save a staggering 65 lives annually, far exceeding initial estimates. The proposed reduction from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would not only save lives but also lead to a significant decrease in serious injuries on the UK's roads. According to the research conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, the move would result in 230 fewer serious injuries compared to 2003. This reduction in road accidents would have a substantial economic impact, saving the country an estimated £119 million annually. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, had previously suggested that such a move could save 50 lives a year, highlighting the significance of this new research. As MPs prepare to vote on the government's road safety bill, which includes changes to speeding fines but not the drink-drive limit, this study serves as a timely reminder of the importance of evidence-based policy-making.

original: This paper presents a millimeter-scale cmos 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1$\times$1 $\mu m^2$ diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512$\times$512 $\mu m^2$. Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, the proposed system measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This obviates the need for using power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype asic is fabricated in tsmc 65 nm lp cmos process and consumes the average static power of 0.535 mw under 1.2 v analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the whole system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 mev proton beam setting.
polished: This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1x1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array's design provides a substantial detection area of 512x512 μm². Unlike traditional systems that sense voltage drops caused by radiation, the proposed system innovatively measures the pulse width, i.e., the time it takes for the voltage to return to its baseline. This approach eliminates the need for power-hungry and large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC's 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The system's functionality is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting, demonstrating its potential for real-world applications.

original: Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (avs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that avs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize avs to seek centrally controlled system optimal (so) routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium (ue) seeking avs and human-driven vehicles (hvs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering mixed fleet of avs and hvs.
polished: The controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to significantly reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily allow themselves to be controlled externally by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that aims to incentivize AVs to seek centrally controlled system-optimal routing by saving on tolls while user equilibrium-seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs) are subject to a congestion charge. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization problem, in which dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, whereas the lower level is a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model considering a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

original: Optomechanics and electromechanics have made it possible to prepare macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, in quadrature squeezed states, and in entangled states of motion. In addition to coaxing ever larger and more tangible objects into a regime of quantum behavior, this new capability has encouraged ideas of using mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. But the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Indeed, early optomechanical proposals noted the possibility to escape this restriction by creating strong quadratic coupling of motion to light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have not yet accessed nonclassical states of motion.
polished: The advent of optomechanics and electromechanics has enabled the creation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This breakthrough has not only facilitated the manipulation of increasingly larger and more tangible objects in a regime of quantum behavior but has also sparked ideas for harnessing mechanical oscillators in the processing and communication of quantum information and as precision force sensors operating beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the effectively linear interaction between motion and light or electricity precludes access to the broader class of quantum states of motion, including cat states or energy squeezed states. Notably, early optomechanical proposals have explored the possibility of circumventing this limitation by creating strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. Although there have been experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, these have yet to access non-classical states of motion.

original: Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers to make decisions. Unfortunately, the evaluations can be manipulated using fake reviews ("spams") by professional spammers, who have learned increasingly insidious and powerful spamming strategies by adapting to the deployed detectors. Spamming strategies are hard to capture, as they can be varying quickly along time, different across spammers and target products, and more critically, remained unknown in most cases. Furthermore, most existing detectors focus on detection accuracy, which is not well-aligned with the goal of maintaining the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address the challenges, we formulate a minimax game where the spammers and spam detectors compete with each other on their practical goals that are not solely based on detection accuracy. Nash equilibria of the game lead to stable detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies.
polished: Online reviews provide customers with product evaluations to inform their purchasing decisions. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be compromised by professional spammers who employ sophisticated and ever-evolving spamming tactics to evade detection. The spamming strategies are notoriously difficult to detect, as they can rapidly adapt to new detection methods, target various products, and remain largely unknown in most cases. Furthermore, existing detectors often prioritize detection accuracy over the trustworthiness of product evaluations. To address these challenges, we propose a novel game-theoretic approach where spammers and spam detectors engage in a dynamic competition with each other, driven by practical goals that are not solely focused on detection accuracy. The resulting Nash equilibria of this game lead to robust detectors that are agnostic to any mixed detection strategies, thereby promoting a more trustworthy and resilient review ecosystem.

original: We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we use the lewis-riesenfeld (l-r) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the l-r invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.
polished: We have developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity population transfer on a three-level quantum system in a lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we utilize the Lewis-Riesenfeld method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the Lewis-Riesenfeld invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an ultra-high-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above 10^-4. The robustness of our shaped pulses is found superior to that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

original: In this paper, we study the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to nonconvexity, there exist multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We show that all local minima share the same form of structure that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture, in the sense that each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and are valid even when the number of components is over-or under-specified. For gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling with the separation between the components.
polished: In this paper, we investigate the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a general number of components. Due to non-convexity, there exist multiple local minima that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima share the same form of structure, which partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture. Specifically, each local minimum involves a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. Our results apply to the setting where the true mixture components satisfy a certain separation condition, and remain valid even when the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results in terms of the scaling between the components, with a notable improvement in the separation between the components.

original: We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the calabi-yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by some suitable subgroup $g$ of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface $ x_m $ in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. The first, berglund-h\"ubsch-krawitz (bhk) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ inside it by some dual group $g^t$. In the second, batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original calabi-yau orbifold. We give a simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.
polished: We examine the connection between the two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup g of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface x_m in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial w_m. The first Berglund-H\"ubsch-Krawitz (BHKS) construction employs another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface x_{m^t} within it by a dual group g^t. In the second Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. We provide a straightforward proof of the equivalence of these two constructions, demonstrating the identical nature of the resulting mirror partners.

original: In this work, a generalization of the study of the human gait was made from already existent models in the literature, like models of keller and kockshenev. In this hybrid model, a strategy of metabolic energy minimization is combined in a race process, with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, trying to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of the experimental data, for different speed regimes, indicate that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a relevant quantity in the quantification of this dynamic. An experimental procedure was put into practice in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences and laboratories of the manuela beltr\'an university in bogot\'a, colombia.
polished: In this study, a comprehensive generalization of the study of human gait was derived from existing models in the literature, including models by Keller and Kockschen. In this hybrid model, a strategy of metabolic energy minimization is integrated into a racing process, with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, aiming to reproduce the behavior of the walk-run transition. The results of the experimental data, for various speed regimes, suggest that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a crucial quantity in the quantification of this dynamic process. An experimental protocol was implemented in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories of the Manuel Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

original: We present a new mixed variable symplectic (mvs) integrator for planetary systems, that fully resolve close encounters. The method is based on a time regularisation that allows keeping the stability properties of the symplectic integrators, while also reducing the effective step size whenever two planets encounter. We use a high order mvs scheme such that it is possible to integrate with large time steps far away from close encounters. We show that this algorithm is able to resolve almost exact collisions (i.e with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) while using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed problem such as the solar system. We demonstrate the long term behaviour on systems of six super-earths experiencing strong scattering for 50 kyr. We compare our algorithm to hybrid methods such as mercury and show that for an equivalent cost we obtain much better energy conservation.
polished: We introduce a novel mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems, capable of resolving close encounters with precision. Our approach is founded on a time-regularization technique that preserves the stability properties of symplectic integrators while adaptively reducing the step size during close encounters between planets. By employing a high-order MVS scheme, we enable the integration of large time steps, even in the presence of distant close encounters. We demonstrate the efficacy of this algorithm in resolving almost exact collisions, with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius, using the same time-step as in weakly perturbed systems, such as the solar system. Our long-term simulations of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50,000 years reveal the stability and accuracy of our approach. We compare our method to hybrid methods like Mercury and show that, for an equivalent computational cost, we achieve significantly better energy conservation.

original: Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In reality, due to the exponentially increasing the hilbert-space dimension with respective to the system size, it is very challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite greenberger-horne-zeilinger (ghz)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. As a comparison, the most efficient witness for ghz-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.
polished: Entanglement is a crucial resource for processing quantum information, as it enables the manipulation of quantum states. One widely employed tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, which guarantees a positive measurement outcome for separable states and can yield a negative result for certain entangled states. However, as the Hilbert space dimension exponentially increases with respect to the system size, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states becomes increasingly challenging. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme necessitates $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurement settings and can withstand up to $1/3$ white noise, demonstrating a significant reduction in the number of measurement settings required for entanglement detection.

original: Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the kerr spacetime, which has a peculiar multipolar structure depending only on its mass and spin. We develop a general method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a large family of horizonless microstate geometries. The latter can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the kerr metric and have a much richer multipolar structure, which provides a portal to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are typically larger (in absolute value) than those of a kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates could place only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission lisa will improve these bounds by orders of magnitude.
polished: In the realm of general relativity, the singular solution for an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, which exhibits a unique multipolar structure solely dependent on its mass and spin. We develop a comprehensive method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes, and apply it to a vast family of horizonless microstate geometries. These latter can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric, revealing a much richer multipolar structure, which provides a gateway to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. Our findings demonstrate that all multipole moments are typically larger in absolute value than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates impose only mild constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will significantly improve these bounds by orders of magnitude, offering a more precise understanding of these enigmatic objects.

original: Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in many domains, such as bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common case in which edges can be short term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both expensive to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To alleviate these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. As temporal attention drives between-node feature propagation, using the dynamics of node interactions to learn this key component provides more flexibility while simultaneously avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.
polished: Reasoning about the evolution of graphs over time is a challenging concept across various domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common scenario where edges can be short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). In practice, long-term edges are often specified by humans. Human-specified edges can be both costly to produce and suboptimal for the downstream task. To address these issues, we propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. By leveraging the dynamics of node interactions to learn this critical component, our approach provides more flexibility while simultaneously mitigating issues associated with human-specified edges.

original: Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (pcw) are reported. The pcw consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (gm) of the pcw for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. Since our pcw has been designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating possible deleterious effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of pcws. Longer term goals are to achieve strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the gms of the pcw, thereby enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.
polished: Observations of thermally driven transverse vibrations in photonic crystal waveguides (PCWs) are reported. The PCW consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between the beams. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW for probe frequencies far from and near to the dielectric band edge. Since our PCW has been designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating the potential detrimental effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the surfaces of PCWs. Long-term goals include achieving strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the GMs of the PCW, thereby enabling optomechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

original: We establish natural splittings for the values of global mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in the splitting comes from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences separate into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various euler classes related to the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.
polished: We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. The interest in this splitting stems from equivariant stable homotopy theory. The equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor, so the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings imply the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$. This decomposition is a fundamental aspect of the study of global equivariant stable homotopy theory, which has far-reaching implications for our understanding of the fundamental structures underlying the geometry and topology of these spaces.

original: Baryonic feedback effects lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression is an important source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as euclid or lsst. In this first paper in a series of two, we use simulations to build a euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, which are both corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of schneider et al. (2019). In addition, we develop an emulator to obtain fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\lambda$cdm cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.
polished: In this paper, we present a comprehensive study on the baryonic feedback effects that lead to a suppression of the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The poorly constrained shape and amplitude of this suppression are a crucial source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys such as Euclid or LSST. As part of a series of two papers, we employ simulations to construct a Euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, both of which are corrected for baryonic effects following the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Furthermore, we develop an emulator to enable fast predictions of the baryonic power suppression, allowing us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard LCDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

original: Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings such as those found in child-centered recordings have been shown to be amongst the most challenging audio files to process. Nevertheless, building speech processing models handling such a wide variety of conditions would be particularly useful for language acquisition studies in which researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of the speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To this end, we gathered diverse child-centered corpora which sums up to a total of 260 hours of recordings and covers 10 languages.
polished: In order to analyze spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, we have discovered that these types of audio files are amongst the most challenging to process. However, developing speech processing models capable of handling such a wide range of conditions would be particularly valuable for language acquisition studies, where researchers are interested in the quantity and quality of the speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early diagnosis and measuring the effects of remediation. In this paper, we present our approach to designing an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. We have gathered diverse child-centered corpora, which totals 260 hours of recordings and encompasses 10 languages.

original: Density-based clustering relies on the idea of linking groups to some specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. The reference to a true, yet unknown, population structure allows to frame the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where the concept of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, draws a correspondence between the groups and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required and a proper selection of the amount of smoothing, governing the shape of the density and hence possibly the modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.
polished: The density-based clustering approach relies on the concept of grouping data points according to specific features of the underlying probability distribution. By referencing an unknown, true population structure, we can frame the clustering problem in a standard inferential framework, where the notion of ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The non-parametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, establishes a correspondence between the clusters and the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a non-parametric density estimate is required, and the proper selection of the amount of smoothing, governing the shape of the density and hence the modal structure, is crucial to identify the final partition. In this work, we address the issue of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective, providing a comprehensive understanding of the underlying statistical principles and their application to the clustering problem.

original: The tails of diboson production at the lhc are sensitive to the interference between standard model and higher dimension operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes set an obstruction to the na\"ive interference contributions of dimension six operators, causing the total diboson rate correction's leading contribution to cancel. In this case, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, recouping sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail, and find that the eft uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable which is only generated by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.
polished: The sensitivity of diboson production at the LHC to the interference between the standard model and higher-dimensional operators, parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics, is a crucial aspect of diboson phenomenology. However, the helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes impose an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, leading to a cancellation of the total diboson rate correction. In this scenario, carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles effectively resurrects the interference, recouping sensitivity to the non-interfering operators. We thoroughly investigate these signatures in detail and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by the construction of an asymmetry variable, which is solely generated by these non-interfering operators. Consequently, the effects of higher-dimensional, interfering operators are relegated to the same status as statistical errors in this observable, rendering them negligible.

original: Causal inference from observational data is the goal of many data analyses in the health and social sciences. However, academic statistics has often frowned upon data analyses with a causal objective. The introduction of the term "data science" provides a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in such a way that it naturally accommodates causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we organize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (which includes causal inference). An explicit classification of data science tasks is necessary to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task. We argue that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a source of widespread misunderstandings about data science.
polished: Data science, as a field, aims to extract causal inferences from observational data, a goal shared by many in the health and social sciences. However, traditional academic statistics has historically been skeptical of data analysis with a causal objective. The introduction of the term "data science" presents a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis in a way that naturally incorporates causal inference from observational data. Like others before, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three classes of tasks  description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction, which includes causal inference. A clear classification of data science tasks is essential to discuss the data, assumptions, and analytics required to successfully accomplish each task. We contend that a failure to adequately describe the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis is a pervasive source of widespread misunderstandings about data science.

original: The weak gravity conjecture (wgc) demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore is that these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it is not clear what is wrong if this doesn't happen. This note shows that, for a generic einstein quantum theory of gravity in ads, exactly stability of extremal black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding the contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the wgc, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general, and it does not rely on either supersymmetry or a particular uv completion, assuming only the validity of einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.
polished: The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) demands the existence of super-extremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. This conjecture is crucial to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it remains unclear what would happen if this does not occur. This note highlights that, in a generic Einsteinian quantum theory of gravity in AdS, the stability of extremal black branes is in tension with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. To avoid this contradiction, a non-perturbative version of the WGC emerges, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general and does not rely on either supersymmetry or a particular UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einstein's gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

original: Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2d) systems can give rise to unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is one of the major unsolved problems in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2d fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, but direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been missing. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2d fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity v$_{\rm c}$. We measure v$_{\rm c}$ as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold fermi gases as a powerful tool for studying the influence of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.
polished: Understanding the profound correlations between two-dimensional (2D) systems is a major open problem in condensed matter physics, particularly in the quest to uncover the underlying mechanisms of unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have emerged as clean and controllable model systems to study the intricate interplay between strong correlations and reduced dimensionality. Despite their promise, direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has remained elusive. In this work, we provide direct evidence of superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by dynamically introducing a periodic potential into the system and monitoring the absence of dissipation below a critical velocity, v_c. Our measurement of v_c as a function of interaction strength reveals a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. This finding establishes ultracold Fermi gases as a powerful tool for investigating the profound impact of reduced dimensionality on the behavior of strongly correlated superfluids.

original: Ordinary differential equation (ode) is a mathematical model used in many application areas such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering with its intuitive appeal to modeling. Despite ode's wide usage in modeling, frequent absence of their analytic solutions makes it difficult to estimate ode parameters from the data, especially when the model has lots of variables and parameters. This paper proposes a bayesian ode parameter estimating algorithm which is fast and accurate even for models with many parameters. The proposed method approximates an ode model with a state-space model based on equations of a numeric solver. It allows fast estimation by avoiding computations of a whole numerical solution in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained by a variational bayes method, more specifically, the approximate riemannian conjugate gradient method (honkela et al.
polished: The ordinary differential equation (ODE) is a mathematical model widely used in various application domains such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, owing to its intuitive appeal in modeling. Despite the widespread use of ODEs in modeling, the frequent absence of their analytical solutions poses a significant challenge in estimating ODE parameters from the data, particularly when the model involves numerous variables and parameters. This paper presents a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is both fast and accurate even for models with many parameters. The proposed method approximates an ODE model with a state-space model based on equations of a numerical solver. It enables fast estimation by avoiding the computation of a complete numerical solution in the likelihood.
