The posterior is obtained via a variational Bayes method, specifically, the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Höhnkel et al.).

original: We study the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry broken weyl semimetal (wsm) in proximity to an $s$-wave superconductor. We find that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the weyl nodes in momentum space. We identify the influence of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Remarkably, we observe a net spin polarization of cooper pairs that are generated via andreev reflection in the two wsm regions. The spin polarization is opposite in the two wsm regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.
polished: We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in junctions formed by a time-reversal symmetry-breaking Weyl semimetal (WSM) in proximity to an s-wave superconductor. Our findings reveal that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes strongly depend on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. Notably, we discover that a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, significantly influences the transport characteristics of the junction. Interestingly, we observe a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. The spin polarization exhibits an opposite sign in the two WSM regions and is highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

original: Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated to be an effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of the ceramic piece, and this approach has been used in a number of applications. Importantly, it provides a method for grading the voltage drop across high voltage insulators, and thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However a concern for the use of the method is the long term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, this especially so if the implanted metal species is readily oxidized. Here we report on our examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. The results indicate that after an initial drop of as much as 40% in the first few weeks after implantation, the conductivity shows only a very slow decrease of about 10% over the following year.
polished: Metal ion implantation into ceramics has been demonstrated as an effective and controllable method for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic pieces, with significant implications for a wide range of applications. Notably, this approach enables the grading of the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, thereby increasing the maximum operational voltage that can be applied across the insulator without surface flashover. However, a key concern for the use of this method is the long-term stability of the implantation-induced conductivity, particularly when the implanted metal species is prone to oxidation. In this study, we report on our comprehensive examination of the long-term behavior of the surface conductivity of titanium-implanted alumina. Our findings indicate that, following an initial drop of up to 40% in the first few weeks post-implantation, the conductivity exhibits a remarkably slow decrease of approximately 10% over the subsequent year, demonstrating a promising stability and potential for long-term reliability in various industrial applications.

original: We introduce a novel skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons based on the idea of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is equivalent to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. In addition, there exist singular configurations that can be identified as n_f=1 baryons charged under the new symmetry. Under this identification, the vector mesons play the role of the chern-simons vector fields living on the quantum hall droplet that forms the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current is the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal gives a unified picture for the two types of baryons and allows them to continuously transform one to the other in a natural way. In addition, chern-simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a result of seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.
polished: We introduce a groundbreaking concept for a novel Skyrme-like conserved current within the framework of the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, rooted in the paradigm of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge is analogous to the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Furthermore, we demonstrate the existence of singular configurations that can be identified as n_f=1 baryons charged under the novel symmetry. Under this identification, the vector mesons assume the role of Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the n_f=1 baryon. We propose that this current represents the correct effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal yields a unified framework for the two types of baryons, enabling a natural, continuous transformation between them. Moreover, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a consequence of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

original: Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in josephson junctions offers an intriguing way to combine anomalous hall and josephson physics in a single device. We study theoretically how the superposition of both effects impacts superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions' transport properties. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface creates sizable transverse hall supercurrents, to which we refer as anomalous josephson hall effect currents. We generalize the furusaki-tsukada formula, which got initially established to quantify usual (tunneling) josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes are widely adjustable by means of the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a clear spectroscopic fingerprint of josephson junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.
polished: Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents a fascinating opportunity to merge anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. We theoretically investigate how the superposition of both effects influences the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. The transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates significant transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially established to quantify traditional (tunneling) Josephson current flows, to evaluate the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes can be widely adjusted through the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. Moreover, the well-localized subgap bound states that form around the interface serve as a clear spectroscopic fingerprint of Josephson junctions.

original: Following the suggestion from the monte--carlo experiments in jim\'enez, j. Of turbul. 2020), that dipoles are as important to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is found that the kinetic energy of this flow is carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a family of small fast-moving cores, and another family of larger slowly moving ones, which can be described as `frozen' into a slowly evolving `crystal'. The kinematics of both families are very different, and only the former is self-similar. The latter is responsible for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, and its vortices form the dipoles and the streams. Mechanisms are discussed for the growth of this slow component.
polished: In a recent study published by Jimenez et al. in 2020, following the Monte Carlo experiments, it was found that dipoles play a crucial role in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence. The kinetic energy of this flow is primarily carried by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. These streams separate into two distinct families  small, fast-moving cores and larger, slowly moving ones that can be thought of as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of these two families exhibit distinct characteristics, with the former being self-similar, while the latter is responsible for the majority of the kinetic energy in the flow. The vortices formed by the latter are the dipoles and the streams, and mechanisms are proposed for the growth of this slow-moving component.

original: Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely useful framework for the design of several quantum algorithms. Often, the running time of quantum algorithms in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time: the time required by the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. In this article, we provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. In particular, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, improving their hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor: from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Furthermore, our methods also help to exponentially improve the dependence on precision of the continuous-time quantum walk based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible markov chain by chakraborty et al.
polished: Continuous-time quantum walks have proven to be an extremely valuable framework for designing various quantum algorithms. The running time of quantum algorithms within this framework is typically characterized by the quantum hitting time  the time required for the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with a high probability. In this article, we present improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time that can be applied to several continuous-time quantum walk-based quantum algorithms. Specifically, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, significantly improving their hitting time upper bound from O(n^5) to O(n^2 log n). Moreover, our methods also enable exponential improvements in the precision of the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to locate a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain, as demonstrated by Chakraborty et al.

original: Extreme mass ratio inspirals (emris) can be classified as dry emris and wet emris based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the "loss-cone") emris, previsouly considered as the main emri sources for the laser interferometer space antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative emri formation channel: (wet) emri formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (mbhs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that are intially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the mbh - this process boosts the formation rate of emris in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.
polished: The extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or the 'loss-cone') EMRIs, previously considered as the primary EMRI sources for the laser interferometer space antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel  wet EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes that are initially moving on inclined orbits, and subsequently drives them to migrate towards the MBH, boosting the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies by orders of magnitude.

original: When a new user just signs up on a website, we usually have no information about him/her, i.e. No interaction with items, no user profile and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, we still expect our recommender systems could attract the users at the first time so that the users decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls into new user cold-start category and it is crucial to the development and even survival of a company. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, e.g. Setting up an interview process, or make use of side information [10] such as user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to take the interview and side information on cold-start users is usually not available.
polished: When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about him or her, i.e., no interaction with items, no user profile, and no social links with other users. Under such circumstances, it is crucial for our recommender systems to effectively attract the users at the first interaction, so that the users decide to stay on the website and become active users. This problem falls under the category of new user cold-start, and it is crucial to the development and survival of a company. Existing works on user cold-start recommendation either require additional user efforts, such as setting up an interview process, or making use of side information, such as user demographics, locations, social relations, etc. However, users may not be willing to provide the interview and side information on cold-start users is usually not available, which can hinder the effectiveness of these methods.

original: Deep learning has solved many problems that are out of reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even though the current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been obtained by learning individual parts of a receiver, a better approach is to jointly learn the whole receiver. This, however, often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is infeasible to implement. To this end, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which executes the whole receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5g-compliant fashion. We facilitate accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols.
polished: Deep learning has successfully addressed numerous problems that were previously out of reach for heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, even in cases where the current radio systems are well-established and optimal algorithms exist for many tasks. While some gains have been achieved by learning individual components of a receiver, a more effective approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. However, this often results in a challenging non-linear problem, for which the optimal solution is infeasible to implement. To address this, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which processes the entire receiver pipeline from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits in a 5G-compliant manner. We facilitate accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols, thereby ensuring optimal performance and reliability in wireless communications.

original: Mutation-based fuzzing typically uses an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) from which to generate new inputs by mutation. A corpus of potential seeds will often contain thousands of similar inputs. This lack of diversity can lead to wasted fuzzing effort by exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To address this, fuzzers come with distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds that triggers the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Common practice suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we explore systematically. We present results of 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to understand their impact in finding bugs in real-world software.
polished: Mutation-based fuzzing typically employs an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs, a corpus, from which to generate novel inputs through mutation. To ensure efficient fuzzing, it is crucial to select a diverse set of seeds that effectively cover the same range of instrumentation data points as the comprehensive corpus. The lack of diversity in seed inputs can lead to wasted fuzzing effort, as exhaustive mutation from all available seeds can be time-consuming and resource-intensive. To address this, fuzzers often come equipped with distillation tools, such as afl-cmin, that enable the selection of the smallest subset of seeds that triggers the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. Our research suggests that minimizing the number and cumulative size of the seeds leads to more efficient fuzzing, which we systematically investigate. We present the results of 34 CPU-years of fuzzing with five distillation approaches to understand their impact in identifying bugs in real-world software.

original: In this paper we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into several groups in each of which the agents have similar (isomorphic) state transition structures, and thus can be relabeled into the same template. Based on the template a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents is designed for the case of partial observation. The scalable supervisor under partial observation does not need to be recomputed regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.
polished: In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be categorized into several groups, each comprising agents with isomorphic state transition structures, which can be relabeled to the same template. To design a scalable supervisor whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents, we propose a supervisor that does not require recalculation regardless of how many agents are added to or removed from the system. We generalize our earlier results to partial observation by deriving sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor on the template level. An illustrative example is provided to demonstrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

original: Electric network frequency (enf) fluctuations constitute a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for enf estimation is introduced with temporal windowing based on the filter-bank capon spectral estimator. A type of gohberg-semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is used due to the toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. Moreover, this approach uses, for the first time in the field of enf, a temporal window, not necessarily the rectangular one, at the stage preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are employed for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed approach outperforms the state-of-the-art methods in enf estimation, when a short time window of $1$ second is employed in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields highly accurate results with respect to both time complexity and accuracy.
polished: The proposed approach introduces an efficient method for estimating electric network frequency fluctuations, which is a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. The approach utilizes a novel temporal windowing strategy based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator, which exploits the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix. The Goergen-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is employed, providing a more efficient computation of the matrix inverse. Furthermore, this method innovatively employs Krylov matrices for fast implementation of matrix inversions. Notably, this approach outperforms state-of-the-art methods in electric network frequency estimation when utilizing a short time window of 1 second in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed method achieves highly accurate results in terms of both time complexity and accuracy.

original: The direpack package aims to establish a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the python universe as a single, consistent package. The dimension reduction methods included resort into three categories: projection pursuit based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust m estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are provided as well, ranging from classical principal component regression up to sparse partial robust m regression. The package also contains a set of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Finally, direpack has been written consistent with the scikit-learn api, such that the estimators can flawlessly be included into (statistical and/or machine) learning pipelines in that framework.
polished: The direpack package aims to establish a comprehensive and modern set of statistical dimension reduction techniques within the Python universe as a single, unified package. The dimension reduction methods included in this package are categorized into three distinct categories  projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. As a corollary, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are also provided, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M-regression. The package also includes a suite of classical and robust pre-processing utilities, including generalized spatial signs, as well as dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Furthermore, direpack has been written to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, ensuring that the estimators can seamlessly be integrated into statistical and/or machine learning pipelines within that framework.

original: The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been widely applied for the high spatial resolution optical imaging. Here, we studied the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. The fluorescence reduction was observed with high power laser excitation. It increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission, and changed the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We used a differential excitation protocol to extract the high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was improved approximate 1.6 times in comparison with the confocal microscopy. Due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method can be used for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with the defects in solids.
polished: The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been extensively applied for high-resolution optical imaging, particularly in the spatial resolution domain. In this study, we investigated the fluorescence anomalous saturation effect of nitrogen vacancy defects in diamond. The fluorescence reduction was observed under high-power laser excitation, which increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altered the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. We employed a differential excitation protocol to extract high-spatial-frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, the spatial resolution of imaging was enhanced, approximately 1.6 times higher than that of confocal microscopy, due to the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing. This method is expected to be applicable for improving the spatial resolution of sensing and biological labeling with defects in solids.

original: When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the usual approach of employing individual survey weights (constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer produces asymptotically unbiased inference. We construct a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We contrast our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration to reveal that only the bayesian method achieves both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data example for a survey of business establishments demonstrate the utility of our approach across different modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a capstone for recent developmental efforts that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the bayesian modeling paradigm and provides a bridge across the two rich but disparate sub-fields.
polished: When we correlate random effects with sample design variables, the traditional approach of using individual survey weights, constructed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities, no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference when employed. We develop a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. Our approach contrasts with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, revealing that only the Bayesian method attains both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real-data examples, including a survey of business establishments, demonstrate the versatility of our approach across various modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a culmination of recent developments that combine traditional survey estimation approaches with the Bayesian modeling paradigm, providing a bridge between the two distinct but complementary subfields.

original: Low-symmetry 2d materials---such as res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-iv monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, among others---have more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely new properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also take place due to low symmetry. The "beyond graphene: low-symmetry and anisotropic 2d materials" special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.
polished: Low-symmetry two-dimensional materials, including res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, and others, exhibit significantly more complex atomistic structures than the traditional honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials give rise to a plethora of inhomogeneous phenomena, including electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as entirely novel properties such as ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Furthermore, novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can occur due to the low symmetry. The 'Beyond Graphene  Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials' special topic was curated to showcase recent experimental and theoretical research on these exciting emerging materials.

original: Orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups was studied using the kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, in contrast to low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be presented by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These main processes replace each other in a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy also made it possible to distinguish two processes of orientational relaxation: the first is due to rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with motion of the main chain segments.
polished: The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were investigated using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was found that in a mesogenic polymer, in contrast to low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence of a melt above the temperature of the nematic-isotropic phase transition can be described by a sum of several exponential processes, two of which play a decisive role. These primary processes exhibit a reciprocal relationship, replacing each other in a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees Celsius. Dielectric spectroscopy also enabled the distinction of two processes of orientational relaxation  the first is attributed to the rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is associated with the motion of the main chain segments.

original: Deep hashing methods have shown great retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. How to optimize discrete hash bits is always the focus in deep hashing methods. A common strategy in these methods is to adopt an activation function, e.g. $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm may make more and more hash bits stuck into the wrong saturated area of the activation functions and never escaped. We call this problem "dead bits problem~(dbp)". Besides, the existing quantization loss will aggravate dbp as well. In this paper, we propose a simple but effective gradient amplifier which acts before activation functions to alleviate dbp.
polished: In deep hashing methods, the primary focus is on optimizing discrete hash bits for large-scale image retrieval. A common strategy employed in these methods is to adopt an activation function, such as the sigmoid or tanh function, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this paradigm may lead to a phenomenon where more and more hash bits become stuck in the saturated region of the activation functions and fail to escape. We refer to this issue as the 'dead bits problem.' Furthermore, the existing quantization loss exacerbates the 'dead bits problem.' In this paper, we propose a simple yet effective gradient amplifier that operates before activation functions to mitigate the 'dead bits problem'.

original: We study the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero su(2) triplet scalar whose existence is motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the standard model higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the lhc and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass less than $230\ \mathrm{gev}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence level.
polished: We investigate the phenomenology of a hypothetical hypercharge-zero triplet scalar, driven by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider both the possibility that the triplets are stable and contribute to the dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the standard model Higgs boson. The former is constrained by the absence of charged track searches at the LHC and by dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multi-lepton collider searches. Our findings indicate that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, whereas an unstable triplet with a mass less than 230 GeV is excluded at 95% confidence level.

original: This paper shows that the eccentric debris rings seen around the stars fomalhaut and hd 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (sometimes referred to as "pericenter glow"). The standard scenario posits an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity is increased to $e_f$ after the gas disc has dispersed by secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. In a minor modification of this scenario, narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, a primordial eccentricity could alternatively be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets.
polished: This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings surrounding the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than expected in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario, often referred to as the "pericenter glow" phenomenon. The standard scenario postulates an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis a, whose eccentricity is increased to ef after the gas disc has dispersed by secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width 2ae_f. In a minor modification of this scenario, narrower belts can arise if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, which could result from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. Alternatively, a primordial eccentricity could be caused by instabilities that increase the disc eccentricity, without the need for any planets. This alternative scenario highlights the potential for the formation of narrow debris rings in the early stages of planetary system formation.

original: An electron is usually considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more, for its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons? in one dimension (1d), the physics of interacting electrons is captured well at low energies by the tomonaga-luttinger-liquid (tll) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1d gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, together with the emergence of three additional 1d 'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1d inter-subband screening by over 45%.
polished: In a typical scenario, an electron is generally considered to possess only one type of kinetic energy. However, it is theoretically possible that it could have more, considering its spin and charge, or by exciting other electrons. In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is well captured by the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model at low energies. However, little has been experimentally observed beyond this linear regime. In this work, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated-wires using a tunnelling spectroscopy technique. Our results reveal two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, as well as the emergence of three additional 1D'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is modulated by varying the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by more than 45%.

original: $context$. The assembly history experienced by the milky way is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the $gaia$ mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. $aims$. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the milky way has experienced. $methods$. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by $gaia$ for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin we analysed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. $results$. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.
polished: The assembly history of the Milky Way is currently being unveiled, thanks to the data provided by the Gaia mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the Milky Way has experienced. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by Gaia for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. The results reveal that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

original: The estimation of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is a fundamental step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article illustrates intrinsic, an r package that implements novel state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators of the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. In detail, the methods included in this package are the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To allow these novel estimators to be easily accessible, the package contains a few high-level, intuitive functions that rely on a broader set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic encompasses models that fall into two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category contains the two-nn and gride models. The functions dedicated to these two methods carry out inference under both the frequentist and bayesian frameworks. In the second category we find hidalgo, a bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient gibbs sampler is implemented.
polished: The estimation of the intrinsic dimensionality of a dataset is a crucial step in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article presents an R package called intrinsic, which implements novel, state-of-the-art likelihood-based estimators for the intrinsic dimension of a dataset. The package includes three novel methods  the two-NN, gride, and hidalgo models. To facilitate the use of these novel estimators, the package provides a set of high-level, user-friendly functions that rely on a comprehensive set of efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic dimension estimators can be categorized into two categories  homogeneous and heterogeneous models. The first category includes the two-NN and gride models, which are designed to perform inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The second category comprises the hidalgo model, a Bayesian mixture model, for which an efficient Gibbs sampler is implemented. This package enables researchers to easily access and utilize these novel estimators in their analysis.

original: Spintronic nanodevices have ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale that promises to enable spintronic reservoir computing (rc) system. Here two physical rc systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (msm) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (stnos) were proposed and modeled to process image classification task and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Based on our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of msm and stno with current pulses stimulation, the handwritten digits recognition task domesticates that an rc system using one single msm has the outstanding performance on image classification. In addition, the complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can also be well solved by a physical rc system consisted of 24 stnos confirmed in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and narma10 tasks.
polished: Spintronic nanodevices have exhibited ultra-fast, nonlinear dynamic, and recurrent behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs) were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNOs to current pulses stimulation revealed that a handwritten digits recognition task can be domesticated by an RC system using a single MSM, which demonstrated outstanding performance in image classification. Furthermore, complex, unknown nonlinear dynamic problems can be well-solved by a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOs in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

original: Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms ranging from search engines to recommender systems. In this paper, we identify a surprising consequence of popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items reporting a given signal, the higher the share of the overall traffic they collectively attract. This few-get-richer effect emerges in settings where there are few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. We demonstrate analytically that the few-get-richer effect emerges when people tend to click on top-ranked items and have heterogeneous preferences for the classes of items. Using simulations, we analyze how the strength of the effect changes with assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also test our predictions experimentally in an online experiment with human participants. Our findings have important implications to understand the spread of misinformation.
polished: Ranking algorithms play a crucial role in online platforms, encompassing search engines and recommender systems. This paper reveals a counterintuitive consequence of popularity-based rankings  the fewer items reporting a given signal, the more they collectively attract a larger share of the overall traffic. This few-get-richer effect arises in settings where there are only a few distinct classes of items (e.g., left-leaning news sources versus right-leaning news sources), and items are ranked based on their popularity. Our analysis demonstrates that this phenomenon emerges when individuals tend to click on top-ranked items and have diverse preferences for the classes of items. Using simulations, we examine how the strength of the effect changes under different assumptions about the setting and human behavior. We also conduct an online experiment with human participants to validate our predictions. Our findings have significant implications for understanding the spread of misinformation and misinformation.

original: Weight pruning has been widely acknowledged as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (dnn), thereby achieving acceleration on various platforms. However, most of the pruning techniques are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity which lead to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To solve the problem, we introduce a new sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity that comprises pattern and connectivity sparsity, and becoming both highly accurate and hardware friendly. With carefully designed patterns, the proposed pruning unprecedentedly and consistently achieves accuracy enhancement and better feature extraction ability on different dnn structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework also achieves pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning and weight training simultaneously. Our approach on the new pattern-based sparsity naturally fits into compiler optimization for highly efficient dnn execution on mobile platforms.
polished: Weight pruning, a widely recognized technique, has been successfully employed as a straightforward and effective method to eliminate redundancy in deep neural networks (DNNs), thereby achieving accelerated performance on various platforms. However, most pruning methods are essentially trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, leading to impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration performance. To address this issue, we introduce a novel sparsity dimension, namely pattern-based sparsity, which encompasses pattern and connectivity sparsity, and achieves both high accuracy and hardware friendliness. By designing carefully crafted patterns, our proposed pruning approach consistently and unprecedentedly enhances accuracy and improves feature extraction capabilities on various DNN structures and datasets, and our pattern-aware pruning framework also facilitates pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern, and connectivity pruning, as well as weight training, simultaneously. Our approach, grounded in the new pattern-based sparsity, naturally fits seamlessly into compiler optimization for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

original: Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events that have different effects on the groups. Constructing a more closely matched control group by matching a subset of the overall control group to the treated group may result in less bias. We study this phenomenon in simulation studies. We study the effect of mountaintop removal mining (mrm) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that makes use of the increase in mrm following the 1990 clean air act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of mrm on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95\% confidence interval that contains substantial adverse effects along with no effect and small beneficial effects.
polished: The analysis of differences-in-differences between a control group that exhibits considerable variation from a treated group is susceptible to bias from historical events that have distinct impacts on the groups. To mitigate this bias, constructing a more closely matched control group by selecting a subset of the overall control group that closely mirrors the treated group can result in a more accurate comparison. We investigate this phenomenon in simulation studies. In our study, we examine the impact of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that leverages the increase in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For a difference-in-differences analysis of the effect of MRM on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval that encompasses substantial adverse effects, as well as small beneficial effects.

original: When constructing models to summarize clinical data to be used for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done by means of visual predictive checks (vpc), which consist of (1) several reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is straightforward to apply, in general. Here we consider the application of the method to time to event data and consider the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.
polished: When constructing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is advisable to assess the models' capacity to replicate the data. This can be achieved by performing visual predictive checks (VPCs), which involve (1) several replications of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) estimating values of interest for each simulated study and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This is a straightforward method that can be generally applied, particularly when considering the application to time-to-event data and taking into account the special case when a time-varying covariate is not known or cannot be approximated after event time.

original: Novel concepts, perspectives and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are shown. We discuss how similar protocols, relying both on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can allow to: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system is transferred into a target quantum state by means of stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing in the frequency domain the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor. The achievement of these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus bringing advances to quantum science and technologies.
polished: The article presents novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system through sequential schemes. We discuss how similar protocols, relying on both repeated quantum measurements and dynamic decoupling control pulses, can enable us to  (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with the zeno physics, thereby ensuring the integrity of the quantum system. (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system will be transferred into a target quantum state through stochastic sequential measurements. (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing the filter functions driving the designed quantum-sensor, thereby enhancing our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thereby advancing quantum science and technology.

original: Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be so embarrassing. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster, you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death.see, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try and overcome it.to start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, "what if people think i'm awful and i'm an idiot?"
polished: As you stand at the podium, your palms grow sweaty, your heart races, and your stomach is in knots. You can't help but feel a sense of panic wash over you, as if you're about to be overwhelmed. Not only is your throat constricted, making it difficult to breathe, but the thought of speaking in front of others is mortifying. You're not being stalked by a monster, but rather, you're speaking in public, a prospect that can be perceived as worse than death. When you're dead, you feel nothing; but when you're at a podium, you feel a sense of stage fright. It's a universal experience that we've all had to endure, as humans, social creatures that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you can't help but think, 'What if people think I'm awful and I'm an idiot?' The fear of public speaking is a natural response, and it's essential to understand what stage fright is to overcome it.

original: I can't think of anyone who just has one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their life. [the way we work]around 15 percent of american workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. They're half-time, part-time, contract workers or temps. The term "side hustle" just seems to fit with this ethos where people are putting together a few different things to make a living.the word "side hustle" has its roots in popular african american newspapers. In the 1920s, these papers used the word "hustle" to refer to some kind of scam. By the 1950s, they were using "side hustle" to refer to legitimate work, too. A side hustle is a little different than a second job. A second job is about necessity.
polished: I'd argue that no one has only one interest in life, and that's all they want to do for the rest of their existence. According to statistics, around 15% of American workers don't have traditional full-time jobs. Instead, they're part-time, freelance, contract workers, or temps. The concept of a "side hustle" seems to align with this modern ethos, where individuals are piecing together a variety of activities to create a sustainable livelihood. The term "side hustle" has its roots in African American newspapers of the 1920s, where it initially referred to some kind of scheme. By the 1950s, it had evolved to describe legitimate work, and today it's often used to describe a secondary, albeit entrepreneurial, pursuit. A side hustle is distinct from a second job, as it's often driven by passion and personal fulfillment, rather than mere necessity.

original: Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by her.michelangelo said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was michelangelo's only tool. But living things are not chiseled. They grow. And in our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information that's required for every other cell to function and to replicate.tools also have consequences. At least since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.
polished: The stark contrast between two design cultures stands out in stark relief. One is a vast, intricate tapestry woven from thousands of steel components, while the other is a delicate, single thread of silk. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed upon the environment, the other creates it. Michelangelo once gazed upon raw marble, he saw a figure yearning to be set free. His chisel was his only tool. However, living organisms are not chiseled, they grow. In our smallest units of life, our cells, we harbor all the information necessary for every other cell to function and replicate. Similarly, tools have consequences. Since the industrial revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production, leading to a profound shift in the way we approach design.

original: Hello. My name is simone. You know how people tell you if you get nervous when onstage, picture people in the audience naked? like it's this thing that's supposed to make you feel better. But i was thinking — picturing all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and wrong. Like, we're working really hard on moving past stuff like that, so we need a new method of dealing with if you get nervous onstage. And i realized that what i'd really like is that i can look at you as much as you're looking at me — just to even things out a little bit. So if i had way more eyeballs, then we'd all be really comfortable, right?
polished: Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people often tell you to calm down when you're feeling anxious before going on stage, and that imagining people in the audience are fully clothed can help. However, I was thinking that picturing everyone in the audience unclothed in 2018 felt somewhat unusual and awkward. As we're working hard to overcome past experiences like that, we need a new approach to handle anxiety when we're on stage. And I realized that what I would really like is being able to look at you as much as you're looking at me - just to see things from a slightly different perspective. If I had more eyes, then we would all be incredibly comfortable, I believe.

original: "to do two things at once is to do neither." it's a great smackdown of multitasking, isn't it, often attributed to the roman writer publilius syrus, although you know how these things are, he probably never said it. What i'm interested in, though, is — is it true? i mean, it's obviously true for emailing at the dinner table or texting while driving or possibly for live tweeting at ted talk, as well. But i'd like to argue that for an important kind of activity, doing two things at once — or three or even four — is exactly what we should be aiming for.look no further than albert einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.
polished: It's a fascinating observation that doing two things at once is often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, but it's unlikely he ever actually said it. What's more intriguing is whether the statement is indeed true. While it's self-evident that doing two things at once may not be suitable for tasks like checking email or texting while driving, it's an entirely different story when it comes to important activities. In fact, doing multiple tasks simultaneously can be incredibly beneficial, as demonstrated by the renowned physicist Albert Einstein. In 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers, showcasing the value of multitasking in his work. The key is to identify the tasks that can be done concurrently, leveraging the benefits of multitasking to achieve remarkable results.

original: I know this is going to sound strange, but i think robots can inspire us to be better humans. See, i grew up in bethlehem, pennsylvania, the home of bethlehem steel. My father was an engineer, and when i was growing up, he would teach me how things worked. We would build projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart that we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, he came home, when i was about 10 years old, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build ... A robot.a robot.
polished: I know this may seem unusual, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better humans. Growing up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, the birthplace of Bethlehem Steel, I had a unique upbringing. My father, an engineer, would teach me about the inner workings of things. We would collaborate on projects, such as model rockets and slot cars. Here's a photo of the go-kart we built together. That's me behind the wheel, accompanied by my sister and my best friend at the time. And one day, when I was around 10 years old, he came home, and at the dinner table, he announced that for our next project, we were going to build a robot, a robot, a machine that would learn and adapt to its environment, a true marvel of engineering and innovation.

original: Sustainability represents the what, the where and the how of what is caught. The who and the why are what's important to me. I want to know the people behind my dinner choices. I want to know how i impact them. I want to know how they impact me. I want to know why they fish. I want to know how they rely on the water's bounty for their living. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perception of seafood away from a commodity to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're also so fortunate to eat.so what do we call this? i think we call it restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.
polished: Sustainability represents the essence, the context, and the methodology of what is caught. The who and the why are what's crucial to me. I desire to know the individuals behind my dinner choices. I desire to know how I impact them. I desire to know how they impact me. I desire to know why they thrive. I desire to know how they rely on the ocean's bounty for their survival. Understanding all of this enables us to shift our perspective of seafood away from a resource to an opportunity to restore our ecosystem. It allows for us to celebrate the seafood that we're fortunate to consume. I believe we can call this concept restorative seafood. Where sustainability is the capacity to endure and maintain, restorative is the ability to replenish and progress.

original: The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of charles dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of dickens's writing that make it so special?dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience wanting more. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.
polished: The star-crossed orphan yearning for a second helping of gruel. The spinster, lost in her tattered wedding dress, is a haunting figure from the works of Charles Dickens. The stone-hearted miser, haunted by the ghost of Christmas past, is another recognizable character from the author's body of work. More than a century after his death, these characters remain iconic figures from the work of Charles Dickens. So striking is his body of work that it has given rise to its own adjective - "Dickensian". But what are the features of Dickens's writing that make it so captivating? Dickens's fiction abounds with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These features of his work kept his audience enthralled. When first published, his stories were serialized, meaning they were released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals and only later reprinted as books.

original: Shah rukh khan: courage, determination, and a single-minded vision. These are the qualities the biggest achievers have in common. These are those brave hearts for whom failure is not an option. What looks to us an unconquerable sea, to our next speaker is an irresistible stage she was born to perform on. So let's dive straight into the story of our fearless speaker, bhakti sharma, who's making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. Bhakti sharma. And 20 minutes later, that two-and-a-half-year-old finds herself completely submerged in water.
polished: Shah Rukh Khan's mantra for success - courage, determination, and a laser-like focus on a singular vision. These are the qualities that define the greatest achievers, who refuse to accept failure as an option. What may seem like an insurmountable challenge to us, is merely an irresistible stage for our next speaker, Bhakti Sharma, who was destined to conquer it. Let us now embark on the remarkable journey of Bhakti Sharma, the fearless swimmer making waves in the world of long-distance swimming. (Applause) Bhakti Sharma  Imagine, on a sweltering summer afternoon in the scorching Rajasthan heat, a two-and-a-half-year-old perched on the back of a moped, with her mother, unaware of their destination. original: I'm going to talk about a technology that we're developing at oxford now, that we think is going to change the way that computer games and hollywood movies are being made.
