Now, before i talk more about that technology, let's have a quick look at what human characters look like at the moment in computer games. This is a clip from a game called "grand theft auto 3." we already saw that briefly yesterday. And what you can see is — it is actually a very good game. It's one of the most successful games of all time.
polished: I'm excited to discuss a revolutionary technology we're currently developing at Oxford, which we believe will revolutionize the way computer games and Hollywood movies are produced. This technology involves simulating humans with a simulated body and a simulated nervous system to control that body. Before diving deeper into the details of this technology, let's first take a brief look at the current state of human characters in computer games. This is a clip from the game 'Grand Theft Auto 3,' which we briefly showcased yesterday. As you can see, it's a highly acclaimed game, and one of the most successful of all time.

original: Like a lot of people around the world, earlier this summer my friends and i were obsessed with the women's world cup held in france. Here we are, watching these incredible athletes, the goals were amazing, the games were clean and engaging, and at the same time, outside the field, these women are talking about equal pay, and in the case of some countries, any pay at all for their sport. So because we were mildly obsessed, we wanted to watch the games live, and we decided that one of the spanish-speaking networks in the us was the best place for us to start. And it wasn't until a few games into the tournament that a friend of mine talks to me and says, "why does it feel like everything i'm seeing is commercials for makeup and household cleaning products and diets?
polished: As millions of people around the world, my friends and I were captivated by the women's World Cup held in France. We found ourselves enthralled by these incredible athletes, mesmerized by the breathtaking goals, and captivated by the seamless execution of the games. Meanwhile, outside the stadium, these women were discussing a pressing issue  equal pay. In some countries, they were not even receiving any compensation for their sport. As we were thoroughly engrossed in the tournament, we decided to watch the games live, and we opted for the Spanish-speaking network in the US as our primary source. It wasn't until a few matches into the tournament that a friend turned to me and posed an astute observation  'Why does it seem like every commercial break is for makeup, household cleaning products, or diets?' This astute observation sparked a deeper conversation about the commercialization of the sport and its impact on the athletes and the game itself.

original: I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about this culture that lived in micronesia in the early 1900s, called the yap. Now, i want to tell you about the yap because their form of money is really interesting. They use these limestone discs called rai stones. Now, the yap don't actually move these rai stones around or exchange them the way we do with our coins, because rai stones can get to be pretty massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. So the yap just keep track of who owns part of what stone.there's a story about these sailors that were transporting a stone across the ocean when they ran into some trouble and the stone actually fell in.
polished:
The Future of Money  A Fascinating Glimpse into the Yap Culture of Micronesia

In the early 1900s, a fascinating culture existed in Micronesia, known as the Yap. The Yap, with their unique monetary system, have a captivating story to share with us. Their form of currency, the rai stones, is particularly intriguing. Unlike our modern coins, these limestone discs can grow to be enormous, with the largest weighing around four tons and measuring 12 feet in diameter. The Yap do not physically move these massive stones around or exchange them like we do with our coins. Instead, they keep track of who owns a portion of the stone. A remarkable story surrounds the sailors who attempted to transport a massive stone across the ocean, only to encounter difficulties that resulted in the stone's unexpected descent into the sea. This captivating tale offers a glimpse into the fascinating world of the Yap and their extraordinary monetary system.

original: You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging?this was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of salem, massachusetts between february 1692 and may 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth.salem was settled in 1626 by puritans, a group of english protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of salem. Battles with their native american neighbors and groups of french settlers were commonplace.
polished: In the midst of a tumultuous era, you find yourself falsely accused of a heinous crime. The prospect of proving your innocence seems insurmountable, and the consequences of being found guilty are dire – execution hangs precariously in the balance. However, if you opt to confess, express remorse, and implicate others, you may be granted clemency. This was the agonizing dilemma faced by those accused of witchcraft in Salem, Massachusetts, between February 1692 and May 1693. These victims of mass hysteria, fueled by superstition and misdirected fervor, were subjected to a justice system that prioritized contrition over truth. The village of Salem, founded by Puritan settlers in 1626, was marked by strict and isolated living conditions. Ongoing conflicts with Native American tribes and French colonists only added to the sense of unease that pervaded the community.

original: There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to fill that demand.what if instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? that’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. We’re not able to print complex organs just yet, but simpler tissues including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange are already in our grasp.bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3-d printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one slice at a time.
polished: There are hundreds of thousands of people on transplant waiting lists, desperately in need of critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could be the difference between life and death. Unfortunately, the number of available donor organs is woefully insufficient to meet the staggering demand. What if, instead of waiting for a match, we could create brand-new, custom-designed organs from scratch? That is the innovative concept behind bioprinting, a cutting-edge branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. While we are not yet able to print complex organs, we are making significant strides in creating simpler tissues, such as blood vessels and tubes responsible for facilitating nutrient exchange and waste elimination, which are crucial for the survival of the human body. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of each other to construct a three-dimensional object one layer at a time.

original: Good afternoon, i'm proud to be here at tedxkrakow. I'll try to speak a little bit today about a phenomenon which can, and actually is changing the world, and whose name is people power. I'll start with an anecdote, or for those of you who are monty python lovers, a monty python type of sketch. Here it is.it is december 15, 2010. Somebody gives you a bet: you will look at a crystal ball, and you will see the future; the future will be accurate. But you need to share it with the world. Ok, curiosity killed the cat, you take the bet, you look at the crystal ball. One hour later, you're sitting in a building of the national tv, in a top show, and you tell the story.
polished: Good afternoon, I'm thrilled to be speaking at TEDxKrakow today. I'd like to share with you a phenomenon that's not only fascinating, but also has the power to transform the world - and its name is people power. I'll begin with a thought-provoking anecdote, reminiscent of a Monty Python-esque sketch. It's December 15, 2010. Someone offers you a bet  you're given a crystal ball, and you're promised that the future you see will be accurate; the only condition is that you must share it with the world. Your curiosity gets the better of you, and you take the bet. One hour later, you find yourself on the set of a national television show, recounting the story to a captivated audience.

original: We're going to begin in 1964. Bob dylan is 23 years old, and his career is just reaching its pinnacle. He's been christened the voice of a generation, and he's churning out classic songs at a seemingly impossible rate, but there's a small minority of dissenters, and they claim that bob dylan is stealing other people's songs.2004. Brian burton, aka danger mouse, takes the beatles' "white album," combines it with jay-z's "the black album" to create "the grey album." "the grey album" becomes an immediate sensation online, and the beatles' record company sends out countless cease-and-desist letters for "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable property. "now, "the grey album" is a remix.
polished: In 1964, Bob Dylan, at the pinnacle of his career at the age of 23, is hailed as the voice of a generation, with a seemingly endless stream of classic songs pouring forth from his creative genius. However, a small but vocal minority raises a dissenting voice, accusing Dylan of plagiarizing the work of others. Fast-forward to 2004, Brian Burton, aka Danger Mouse, takes the Beatles' iconic "White Album" and Jay-Z's "The Black Album" and skillfully fuses them to create "The Grey Album." This innovative mashup, dubbed "The Grey Album," sparks an immediate online sensation, prompting the Beatles' record label to send out a barrage of cease-and-desist letters, citing "unfair competition and dilution of our valuable intellectual property." The label insists that "The Grey Album" is, in fact, a remix.

original: Well, that's kind of an obvious statement up there. I started with that sentence about 12 years ago, and i started in the context of developing countries, but you're sitting here from every corner of the world. So if you think of a map of your country, i think you'll realize that for every country on earth, you could draw little circles to say, "these are places where good teachers won't go." on top of that, those are the places from where trouble comes. So we have an ironic problem — good teachers don't want to go to just those places where they're needed the most.i started in 1999 to try and address this problem with an experiment, which was a very simple experiment in new delhi.
polished: While it may seem an obvious statement, I began pondering this issue about 12 years ago, initially in the context of developing countries. However, considering the global scope, I believe it's essential to recognize that every country on the planet has areas where good teachers are sorely needed. If you envision a world map, I think you'll agree that for each country, you could draw circles around regions where the need for quality education is most pressing. Moreover, these are often the very areas from which the greatest challenges arise. We have an intriguing paradox - good educators are often reluctant to venture to places where they are needed most urgently. In 1999, I embarked on an experiment to address this conundrum, starting with a simple initiative in New Delhi.

original: Currently, most refugees live in the cities rather than in the refugee camps. We represent over 60 percent of the number of refugees globally. With the majority of refugees living in urban areas, there is a strong need for a paradigm shift and new thinking. Rather than wasting money on building walls, it would be better to spend on programs to help refugees to help themselves. (applause)we always have to leave behind all our possessions. But not our skills and knowledge. If allowed to live a productive life, refugees can help themselves and contribute to the development of their host country.i was born in the city called bukavu, south kivu, in the democratic republic of congo. I am the fifth-born in a family of 12 children.
polished: Currently, a significant proportion of the world's refugees reside in urban areas, rather than in refugee camps. We account for over 60% of the global refugee population. As the majority of refugees settle in urban areas, there is a pressing need for a paradigm shift and innovative thinking. Rather than expending resources on constructing physical barriers, it would be more effective to allocate funds towards programs that empower refugees to become self-sufficient and contribute to the development of their host countries. (Applause) While we are forced to leave behind our material possessions, we must not abandon our skills and knowledge. If provided the opportunity to lead a productive life, refugees can not only help themselves but also contribute to the growth and prosperity of their host nations. Born in the city of Bukavu, in the Democratic Republic of Congo, I am the fifth-born of a family of 12 siblings.

original: I have two questions for you. One: whose shoulders do you stand on? and two: what do you stand for? these are two questions that i always begin my poetry workshops with students because at times, poetry can seem like this dead art form for old white men who just seem like they were born to be old, like, you know, benjamin button or something. And i ask my students these two questions, and then i share how i answer them, which is in these three sentences that go: i am the daughter of black writers, who are descended from freedom fighters who broke their chains and changed the world. They call me. And these are words i repeat in a mantra before every single poetry performance. In fact, i was doing it in the corner over there. I was making faces.
polished: I pose two questions to you  on whose shoulders do you stand, and what do you stand for? These queries are the opening prompts I use in my poetry workshops, as they often spark insightful discussions about the significance of one's identity and purpose. When I ask these questions, I share my own responses, which are as follows  I am the daughter of black writers, who are the descendants of freedom fighters who broke their shackles and revolutionized the world. These words are a personal mantra I repeat before each poetry performance, and I find solace in their power. In fact, I was reciting them to myself just moments ago, lost in thought as I sat in the corner of the room, making mental faces.

original: (breathes in)(breathes out)so, i didn't always make my living from music. For about the five years after graduating from an upstanding liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughter)i was a self-employed living statue called the eight-foot bride, and i love telling people i did this for a job, because everybody always wants to know, who are these freaks in real life. (laughter)hello.i painted myself white one day, stood on a box, put a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, i handed them a flower — and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, i threw in a gesture of sadness and longing — as they walked away.
polished: (With a deep breath, I exhaled) so, I didn't always make a living from music. For about five years after graduating from an esteemed liberal arts university, this was my day job. (laughs) I was a self-employed living statue known as the eight-foot bride, and I loved telling people I did this for a job, because everyone always wants to know, who are these eccentrics in real life. (laughs) Hello. I once painted myself white one day, stood on a box, placed a hat or a can at my feet, and when someone came by and dropped in money, I handed them a flower – and some intense eye contact. And if they didn't take the flower, I threw in a gesture of sadness and longing – as they walked away.

original: On october 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the soviet union launched sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This little metal ball, smaller than two feet in diameter, launched a space race between the u.s. And u.s.s.r. That would last for eighteen years and change the world as we know it. Sputnik was actually not the first piece of human technology to enter space. That superlative goes to the v-2 rocket used by germany in missile attacks against allied cities as a last-ditch effort in the final years of world war ii. It wasn't very effective, but, at the end of the war, both the u.s. And u.s.s.r. Had captured the technology and the scientists that had developed it and began using them for their own projects.
polished: On October 4, 1957, the world witnessed a momentous occasion as the Soviet Union successfully launched Sputnik, the world's first artificial satellite, into orbit, captivating global attention with a mix of awe and trepidation. This diminutive, roughly two-foot-diameter metal sphere sparked a protracted space race between the United States and the Soviet Union, a competition that would persist for nearly two decades and forever alter the trajectory of human history. Interestingly, Sputnik was not the first human-made object to venture into space. That distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket, developed by Germany during World War II as a desperate last resort to target Allied cities. Although the V-2 proved ineffective, both the United States and the Soviet Union seized the technology and the scientists behind it, incorporating their expertise into their own projects, setting the stage for a new era in space exploration.

original: I am a cultural omnivore, one whose daily commute is made possible by attachment to an ipod — an ipod that contains wagner and mozart, pop diva christina aguilera, country singer josh turner, gangsta rap artist kirk franklin, concerti, symphonies and more and more. I'm a voracious reader, a reader who deals with ian mcewan down to stephanie meyer. I have read the twilight tetralogy. And one who lives for my home theater, a home theater where i devour dvds, video on demand and a lot of television. For me, "law & order: svu," tina fey and "30 rock" and "judge judy" — "the people are real, the cases are real, the rulings are final.
polished: As a self-proclaimed cultural omnivore, my daily commute is facilitated by my attachment to an iPod, which is stocked with a diverse range of music, from the classical masterpieces of Wagner and Mozart to the contemporary hits of pop diva Christina Aguilera, country crooner Josh Turner, and gangsta rap artist Kirk Franklin. In addition to music, my iPod also contains a variety of concertos and symphonies that I enjoy listening to during my daily commute. As an avid reader, I devour books from authors such as Ian McEwan and Stephanie Meyer, having read the entire Twilight tetralogy. When I'm not indulging in literature, I'm often found in my home theater, where I relish devouring DVDs, video-on-demand content, and a wide range of television shows. For me, programs like "Law & Order  SVU," Tina Fey's "30 Rock," and "Judge Judy" are must-watches, with their realistic portrayals of real people, cases, and verdicts.

original: [citizens of the world][we face a global crisis of unprecedented scale][please stand by for a message from ... ][the secretary-general of the united nations antónio guterres]the climate emergency is the defining crisis of our time. We are in a race against time, and we are losing. There is a growing tide of impatience, especially among young people, with global inaction. We need more ambition from all: governments, cities, businesses, investors and people everywhere. So i'm pleased you are launching ted countdown. Your influence and ideas can help accelerate momentum for a carbon-neutral world by 2050. That is the only way to avert the worst impacts of global heating. We have the tools, the science and the resources. Let us now get into this race with political will and energy.
polished: As the Secretary-General of the United Nations, I am compelled to address the global community with a sense of urgency regarding the climate emergency, a crisis of unprecedented scale that imperils our collective future. The clock is ticking, and we are falling behind schedule. The growing discontent among the younger generation, who are rightfully demanding decisive action, is a stark reminder of the need for immediate and collective action. We require unwavering commitment from governments, cities, businesses, investors, and individuals worldwide to join forces and drive the momentum towards a carbon-neutral world by 2050. This is the only viable path to mitigate the catastrophic consequences of global warming. We possess the technological know-how, scientific expertise, and resources to make it happen. Now, let us harness our collective willpower and energy to propel ourselves into this critical race against time, securing a livable future for all.

original: Menstruation. A simple word describing a natural biological process, weighed down by centuries of stigma, has been transformed into something most of us can only speak about in whispers. But why? as i speak to you right now, more than 800 million women around the world are having a period. None of us would exist without it, and yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. From my experience and that of the women around me, i can tell you that it's exhausting.it's exhausting to carefully take out a brown paper bag hiding a pad, stuffing it into your pocket in the middle of a class and rushing to the washroom as discreetly as possible. It's exhausting to sit through lessons and meetings pretending to be absolutely normal, while internally crying out from intense period cramps.
polished: Menstruation  a natural biological process shrouded in centuries of stigma, has undergone a profound transformation, rendering it a topic that most of us dare not discuss openly. As I converse with you now, over 800 million women worldwide are currently experiencing their period. Without it, none of us would exist, yet it remains an "embarrassing" subject to broach. Drawing from my personal experience and that of the women around me, I can attest that it's a grueling ordeal. It's exhausting to carefully extract a discreet pad from a brown paper bag, hastily stash it in one's pocket during a class, and rush to the washroom with an air of furtiveness. It's draining to sit through lessons and meetings, pretending to be utterly composed, while internally struggling to cope with the intense physical discomfort of period cramps.

original: The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the largest and most intact forest in the world, canada's boreal forest. It stretches right across northern canada, in labrador, it's home to the largest remaining wild caribou herd in the world: the george river caribou herd, numbering approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, when i was there, i couldn't find one of them, but you have the antlers as proof.all across the boreal, we're blessed with this incredible abundance of wetlands. Wetlands, globally, are one of the most endangered ecosystems. They're absolutely critical ecosystems, they clean air, they clean water, they sequester large amounts of greenhouse gases, and they're home to a huge diversity of species.
polished: The world's most ambitious and environmentally devastating project, situated in the heart of the largest and most pristine forest on the planet, Canada's boreal forest, stretches across northern Canada, encompassing Labrador, where it is home to the world's largest remaining wild caribou herd, the George River caribou herd, comprising approximately 400,000 animals. Unfortunately, during my visit, I did not have the privilege of encountering one of these majestic creatures, but I do have the antlers as a poignant reminder. Across the boreal forest, we are blessed with an incredible abundance of wetlands, a globally endangered ecosystem. These wetlands play a crucial role in maintaining ecological balance, as they purify the air, purify the water, sequester significant amounts of greenhouse gases, and provide a haven for an astonishing diversity of species.

original: Before the world of humans began, there was the world of the gods, made of fields, plains and gardens. Four brothers wandered this celestial realm. They had no family other than each other— they didn’t even know who their parents were. One of the brothers, deminan, looked different from the others. His skin was covered in painful scabs, and he wondered why he alone had been marked with this affliction.one day, while the supreme spirit yaya was out in his gardens, deminan and his brothers snuck into yaya’s house. After feasting and exploring, they spotted a giant gourd hanging in the corner. But as they tried to look inside the gourd, they dropped it.
polished: In the primordial era, before the dawn of human civilization, the celestial realm was inhabited by four brothers who roamed the vast expanse of the divine domain. This world, comprised of lush fields, rolling plains, and lush gardens, was the domain of these four siblings, who shared a bond of brotherhood, yet remained ignorant of their paternal lineage. Among them, one brother, Deminan, stood apart from the others, his body scarred by painful scabs that seemed to hold the secrets of his mysterious past. One day, while the supreme spirit, Yaya, was absent from his gardens, Deminan and his brothers slipped into Yaya's abode, their curiosity getting the better of them. After feasting on the bounty of Yaya's hospitality, they stumbled upon a colossal gourd suspended from the ceiling, and as they endeavored to uncover its secrets, they inadvertently let it fall.

original: So, i had graduated seven years ago from berkeley with a dual degree in molecular and cell biology and linguistics, and i had gone to a career fair here on campus, where i'd gotten an interview with a start-up called theranos. And at the time, there wasn't really that much information about the company, but the little that was there was really impressive. Essentially, what the company was doing was creating a medical device where you would be able to run your entire blood panel on a finger-stick of blood. So you wouldn't have to get a big needle stuck in your arm in order to get your blood test done. So this was interesting not only because it was less painful, but also, it could potentially open the door to predictive diagnostics.
polished: I graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, with a dual degree in molecular and cellular biology, as well as linguistics, seven years ago. I attended a career fair on campus, where I secured an interview with a startup called Theranos. At the time, there was limited information available about the company, but the little that was known was truly impressive. Essentially, Theranos aimed to revolutionize the medical device industry by creating a device that would enable individuals to run their entire blood panel tests on a finger-stick of blood, eliminating the need for a painful needle prick in the arm. This innovation was exciting not only because it promised to reduce patient discomfort, but also because it had the potential to open the door to more accurate and predictive diagnostic capabilities.

original: My journey to become a polar specialist, photographing, specializing in the polar regions, began when i was four years old, when my family moved from southern canada to northern baffin island, up by greenland. There we lived with the inuit in the tiny inuit community of 200 inuit people, where [we] were one of three non-inuit families. And in this community, we didn't have a television; we didn't have computers, obviously, radio. We didn't even have a telephone. All of my time was spent outside with the inuit, playing. The snow and the ice were my sandbox, and the inuit were my teachers. And that's where i became truly obsessed with this polar realm.
polished: My journey to become a polar specialist, specializing in photographing the polar regions, began at the tender age of four, when my family relocated from southern Canada to northern Baffin Island, Greenland. There, we resided with the Inuit in the tiny Inuit community of 200 residents, where we were one of only three non-Inuit families. In this community, we didn't have the luxury of modern conveniences like television, computers, or radio. Instead, our days were filled with outdoor activities with the Inuit, playing in the snow and ice. The Arctic landscape became my playground, and the Inuit became my mentors. It was during this time that I became deeply fascinated with this polar realm, and my passion for it only grew stronger with each passing day.

original: We're seen as the organization that is the bucket for failed social policy. I can't define who comes to us or how long they stay. We get the people for whom nothing else has worked, people who have fallen through all of the other social safety nets. They can't contain them, so we must. That's our job: contain them, control them.over the years, as a prison system, as a nation, and as a society, we've become very good at that, but that shouldn't make you happy. Today we incarcerate more people per capita than any other country in the world. We have more black men in prison today than were under slavery in 1850.
polished: We are the organization that serves as the safety net for those who have fallen through all other social systems. We provide a haven for individuals who have been failed by society, who have been overlooked by the social safety nets that were designed to protect them. We don't discriminate by gender, race, or any other factor; we accept anyone who has been failed by the system. We understand that our role is not only to contain and control those who come to us, but also to provide a second chance, a chance to rehabilitate and reintegrate into society. Over the years, we have honed our skills and expertise in this area, but our incarceration rates per capita remain higher than those of any other country in the world. It is a sobering reality that we have more black men in prison today than there were under slavery in 1850. This should serve as a stark reminder that our criminal justice system is far from perfect, and that we must continue to work towards a more just and equitable society.

original: I'd like to take you on the epic quest of the rosetta spacecraft. To escort and land the probe on a comet, this has been my passion for the past two years. In order to do that, i need to explain to you something about the origin of the solar system.when we go back four and a half billion years, there was a cloud of gas and dust. In the center of this cloud, our sun formed and ignited. Along with that, what we now know as planets, comets and asteroids formed. What then happened, according to theory, is that when the earth had cooled down a bit after its formation, comets massively impacted the earth and delivered water to earth. They probably also delivered complex organic material to earth, and that may have bootstrapped the emergence of life.
polished: I'm thrilled to embark on the epic quest of the Rosetta spacecraft, a mission that has captivated my attention for the past two years. As we prepare to escort and land the probe on a comet, I'd like to take a moment to share with you the fascinating story of the solar system's origin. Let's journey back in time, approximately 4.5 billion years ago, to a era when a vast cloud of gas and dust enveloped our cosmic neighborhood. At the heart of this primordial cloud, our sun burst forth, igniting the spark of life. As the planets, comets, and asteroids took shape, a pivotal event occurred  the delivery of comets to Earth. According to theory, these celestial bodies, now known as comets, struck our planet with immense force, depositing water and potentially even complex organic matter, which may have jumpstarted the emergence of life on Earth.

original: Chris anderson: hello, ted community, welcome back for another live conversation. It's a big one today, as big as they get. You know, when we created this "build back better" series our thought was how could we address issues arising out of the pandemic, how could we imagine building back from that. But the events of this past week, the horrific death of george floyd and the daily protests that have followed, i mean, they provided a new urgency which we, of course, simply have to address. I mean, can we build back better from this? i think before we can even start to answer that question, we just have to seek to understand the immensity of this moment.whitney pennington rodgers: that's right, chris.
polished: Chris Anderson  Good morning, esteemed community, welcome back to our live conversation. Today's discussion promises to be a significant one, as profound as it is timely. When we conceived the 'Building Back Better' series, our primary concern was how to address the challenges arising from the pandemic, and how we could envision rebuilding from that. However, the tragic death of George Floyd and the ongoing protests that have followed, I mean, they have added a new sense of urgency to our discussion. We must acknowledge that before we can even begin to explore how to build back better from this moment, we must first seek to comprehend the gravity of this moment. Whitney Pennington Rodgers  That's right, Chris.

original: In 1903, the president of the united states took a three-day camping trip in california’s yosemite valley. President theodore roosevelt slept in a grove of towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and spent hours talking around the campfire with his host and guide, conservationist john muir. Roosevelt famously loved the outdoors, but muir had invited him there for more than just camping: yosemite was in danger.though yosemite became protected land in 1864, the valley was still at risk for overdevelopment in 1903. It was at the heart of a decades-old struggle to set aside land for both preservation and public use— two goals that were much easier said than done.the battle over yosemite began with the 1849 gold rush, when miners surged west, seeking gold in the sierra nevada foothills.
polished: In 1903, President Theodore Roosevelt embarked on a three-day camping expedition in California's breathtaking Yosemite Valley, where he spent his nights beneath the towering canopy of ancient sequoia trees. Despite the harsh weather conditions, Roosevelt braved a snowstorm to camp and engage in lengthy conversations around the campfire with his host and guide, renowned conservationist John Muir. As a self-proclaimed outdoorsman, Roosevelt was drawn to the natural beauty of Yosemite, but Muir had invited him to the valley for a more pressing reason  the area was under threat. Although Yosemite had been protected since 1864, the valley remained vulnerable to overdevelopment in 1903. At the heart of a decades-long struggle to balance preservation and public use, the battle for Yosemite had its roots in the 1849 gold rush, when the discovery of gold in the Sierra Nevada foothills triggered a mass migration of miners westward.

original: Hello. This is my first trip, first time in life i'm outside of the walls of gaza. I'm so happy to be here. (applause)my ambition always was to be a pilot, to fly a plane, to feel free to fly the sky, to touch the sky. But that didn't happen. Simply, i live in gaza, there is no airport. All borders are closed on every side. We live in one of the biggest prisons in the world. The only thing i can do is just to look up to the sky. On some days, we are lucky if we have electricity for four or five hours. When it's cold, we make a fire on the front or on the roof of our homes.
polished: I'm thrilled to be embarking on my first trip outside the walls of Gaza, a place I've always called home. As I step out into the open air, I'm filled with an overwhelming sense of excitement and gratitude. My lifelong ambition has been to become a pilot, to soar through the skies, feeling the rush of freedom as I touch the clouds. Unfortunately, life has taken a different turn, and I find myself living in one of the most restricted places on earth, with borders closed on all sides. Despite these challenges, I've learned to find solace in the simple things, like gazing up at the sky. On the rare occasions when we're fortunate enough to have electricity for a few hours, we make do with what we have. And when the cold winter nights arrive, we gather around the warmth of a fire, either on the front porch or on the roof of our homes, finding comfort in the simple joys of life.

original: I am sorry i cannot show you my face, because if i do, the bad guys will come for me.my journey started 14 years ago. I was a young reporter. I had just come out of college.then i got a scoop. The scoop was quite a very simple story. Police officers were taking bribes from hawkers who were hawking on the streets. As a young reporter, i thought that i should do it in a different way, so that it has a maximum impact, since everybody knew that it was happening, and yet there was nothing that was keeping it out of the system.so i decided to go there and act as a seller. As part of selling, i was able to document the hard core evidence. The impact was great. It was fantastic.this was what many call immersion journalism, or undercover journalism.
polished: I am unable to reveal my identity, as doing so would put my life at risk, as the individuals responsible for these illicit activities would likely seek retribution against me. My journey as a journalist began 14 years ago, when I was a young and ambitious reporter, fresh out of college. I had stumbled upon a sensational scoop - the revelation that police officers were accepting bribes from street vendors. As a novice journalist, I recognized the gravity of the situation and the need for a more impactful approach, as everyone was aware of the widespread corruption, yet nothing was being done to address it. I decided to adopt a different strategy, immersing myself in the situation by posing as a vendor myself. Through this undercover reporting, I was able to gather concrete evidence, which had a profound impact. This style of reporting is often referred to as immersion journalism or undercover journalism, a technique that allows for a more in-depth and nuanced understanding of the issue at hand.

original: One simple vitamin can reduce your risk of heart disease.eating chocolate reduces stress in students.new drug prolongs lives of patients with rare disease.health headlines like these are published every day, sometimes making opposite claims from each other. There can be a disconnect between broad, attention-grabbing headlines and the often specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. So how can you avoid being misled by grabby headlines?the best way to assess a headline’s credibility is to look at the original research it reports on. We’ve come up with a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines.keep watching for the explanation of the first example; then pause at the headline to answer the question. These are simplified scenarios.
polished: One simple vitamin can significantly reduce your risk of heart disease. Eating chocolate can reduce stress levels in students, and a new drug has been shown to prolong the lives of patients with rare diseases. Headlines like these are published daily, often presenting opposite claims from one another. There can be a disconnect between the attention-grabbing headlines and the specific, incremental results of the medical research they cover. To avoid being misled by sensationalized headlines, it's essential to assess a headline's credibility by examining the original research it reports on. We've developed a hypothetical research scenario for each of these three headlines. Keep in mind the explanation of the first example, and pause at the headline to answer the question. These are simplified scenarios, but understanding the context is crucial to making informed decisions about the validity of the claims being made.

original: So, when i was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my little brothers from ethiopia. And one day my mom asked, "what day should we put for their birthday?" "uh, the day they were born, obviously?" ridiculous question. And then my mom said, "well, kristen, neither of your little brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you suggest we find out when that was?" mind blown. Now, 20 years later, i'm still working on it, except instead of trying to solve the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, i try to solve this problem globally.so what do birth certificates have to do with international development?
polished: So, when I was 14, my family was in the process of adopting my younger siblings from Ethiopia. One day, my mother asked, "What day should we celebrate for their birthday?" I thought it was a silly question, but then my mother said, "Well, Kristen, neither of your younger brothers have a birth certificate, so how do you propose we determine their date of birth?" It was a mind-blowing revelation. Now, 20 years later, I'm still grappling with this challenge, except instead of trying to unravel the mystery of my brothers' missing birth certificates, I'm now tackling this problem on a global scale. So, what do birth certificates have to do with international development?

original: Imagine if you could plug your brain into a machine that would bring you ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were given the choice to sign up for that kind of existence, would you? that's the question philosopher robert nozick posed through a thought experiment he called the experience machine. The experiment asks us to consider a world in which scientists have developed a machine that would simulate real life while guaranteeing experiences of only pleasure and never pain. The catch? you have to permanently leave reality behind, but you'll hardly know the difference. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life's natural ups and downs will just be replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds great, right?
polished: Envision a machine that could grant you ultimate pleasure for the remainder of your existence. Would you opt for such an existence? That's the thought-provoking question posed by philosopher Robert Nozick through his thought experiment, known as the experience machine. The experiment invites us to contemplate a world where scientists have developed a device that simulates reality, guaranteeing experiences of pure pleasure and eliminating all pain. The catch  you would need to surrender your existence in the natural world, but you wouldn't be aware of the distinction. Your experiences would be indistinguishable from reality, with life's natural ebbs and flows replaced by an unending series of unmitigated highs. It's a tantalizing prospect, isn't it?

original: I would like to tell you about the most embarrassing thing that has ever happened to me in my years of working as a palliative care physician. This happened a couple of years ago. I was asked as a consultant to see a woman in her 70s — retired english professor who had pancreatic cancer. I was asked to see her because she had pain, nausea, vomiting ... When i went to see her, we talked about those symptoms and in the course of that consultation, she asked me whether i thought that medical marijuana might help her. I thought back to everything that i had learned in medical school about medical marijuana, which didn't take very long because i had learned absolutely nothing.
polished: As a palliative care physician, I recall the most embarrassing moment in my career that still resonates with me to this day. It occurred a couple of years ago, when I was asked to consult with a 70-year-old retired English professor who was struggling with pancreatic cancer. Her symptoms were characterized by persistent pain, nausea, and vomiting, which made it challenging to manage her condition. During our consultation, she inquired about the potential benefits of medical marijuana in alleviating her symptoms. As a medical professional, I must admit that my initial response was influenced by my limited knowledge of medical marijuana, which was minimal, as I had not received extensive training on the subject during my medical education. However, I took the opportunity to educate myself on the topic, and I now recognize the importance of considering alternative treatment options for my patients.

original: For the past 24 years, i have been a firefighter in huntington, west virginia. As firefighters, my team and i are tasked with saving lives and property from such disasters as car wrecks, house fires and also life-threatening medical emergencies. I am a woman leading a department in a male-dominated profession.and 10 years ago, i decided to increase my medical knowledge and i received a nursing degree. That was because it became clear that the next big threat facing not only my city, but other cities around the country, was not the one-and-done disaster, where you can ride in like the cavalry, as a firefighter, put out the fire and leave, feeling like you have made a difference and everything is ok.
polished: For the past 24 years, I have been a dedicated firefighter in Huntington, West Virginia. As a firefighter, my team and I are entrusted with the crucial task of saving lives and property from the devastating consequences of disasters such as car accidents, house fires, and life-threatening medical emergencies. As a woman leading a department in a traditionally male-dominated profession, I have made it my mission to continuously upskill and expand my knowledge. Ten years ago, I made the conscious decision to further enhance my medical expertise and earned a nursing degree. This was a pivotal moment, as it became increasingly clear that the next significant threat facing not only my city, but also cities across the country, was not a one-and-done disaster, where you can simply ride in like the cavalry, put out the fire, and leave, feeling like you've made a meaningful impact and everything is resolved. Rather, it was a complex, multifaceted challenge that required a sustained and collaborative effort to mitigate the risks and consequences of these disasters.

original: Where does all the carbon we release go? carbon works in a natural cycle, present in all living things: in the soil, in the oceans, in the atmosphere and in rocks deep underground. When plants and other living things die, much of their stored carbon makes its way back to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb the carbon.but over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock and some becomes fossil fuels: coal, oil and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release some of the carbon trapped in rock. And human activities, like burning fossil fuels, also release some of that prehistoric carbon.today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.
polished: The origin of the carbon dioxide we release is a natural cycle, present in all living organisms  in the soil, oceans, atmosphere, and rocks deep beneath the Earth's surface. When plants and other living organisms die, a significant portion of their stored carbon is gradually released back into the atmosphere, where it is reabsorbed by new plant growth. However, over millions of years, some of the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes trapped in rock formations, and some is transformed into fossil fuels  coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural geological events, such as volcanic eruptions, release some of the carbon that has been trapped in the Earth's crust. Moreover, human activities, like the burning of fossil fuels, also release a substantial amount of prehistoric carbon dioxide. In fact, humans release approximately 60 times more carbon dioxide annually than all the volcanoes on the planet combined.

original: Even nature's most disgusting creatures have important secrets, but who would want a swarm of cockroaches coming towards them?yet one of the greatest differences between natural and human technologies relates to robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and new environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize running over rough terrain. When we put a jet pack on them, or give them a perturbation like an earthquake, we discovered that their wonderfully tuned legs allow them to self-stabilize without using any of their brainpower. They can go over complex terrain like grass, no problem, and not get destabilized. We discovered a new behavior where, because of their shape, they actually roll automatically to their side to go through this artificial test bit of grass.robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
polished: Even the most reviled creatures in nature possess crucial secrets, yet who would willingly invite a swarm of cockroaches towards them? One of the most striking distinctions between natural and human technologies lies in their robustness. Robust systems exhibit remarkable stability in complex and uncharted environments, a trait that is particularly evident in the remarkable ability of cockroaches to self-stabilize while traversing rugged terrain. When equipped with a jet pack or subjected to perturbations such as earthquakes, we observed that their exquisitely tuned legs enable them to self-stabilize without relying on any cerebral processing. Notably, they can navigate intricate terrain like grass with ease, without experiencing destabilization. Our research has uncovered a novel behavior, wherein their unique shape allows them to automatically roll onto their side to traverse artificial grass obstacles. The significance of robust systems lies in their capacity to perform multiple tasks with a single structural framework. Our investigation has yielded a fascinating new behavior, highlighting the remarkable adaptability of these creatures.

polished: In these challenging economic times, I'd like to take a moment to lift your spirits with an inspiring tale of a remarkable, albeit lesser-known, commercial success story from the past two decades. Comparable in its unique way to the achievements of Microsoft or Google, this industry has defied the current recession with remarkable resilience. I'm referring, of course, to the world of organized crime, a phenomenon that has been around for centuries, as you're quick to point out. I've come to refer to this phenomenon as the global shadow economy, or mcmafia, for short. So, what drove this extraordinary growth in cross-border criminal activity?

In contrast, thinking, on the other hand, is often perceived as a more straightforward process, akin to logical reasoning or problem-solving. However, this oversimplification overlooks the actual challenges that arise. For instance, when discussing the role of psychology in addressing health issues, one common problem is the difficulty of tackling the impact of hand hygiene in the Western world.

polished:
Here is a polished version of the original text:

What is a parent? What is a parent? It's not an easy question. Today, we have adopted families, stepfamilies, and surrogate mothers. Many parents face tough questions and difficult decisions. Should we tell our child about the sperm donation? If so, when? What words should we use? Sperm donors are often referred to as "biological fathers," but should we really be using the word "father" as a label? As a philosopher and social scientist, I have been studying these questions about the concept of parenthood. However, today, I will share with you what I learned from talking to parents and children. I will show you that they know what matters most in a family, even though their family may look a little different.

original: When i look in the mirror today, i see a justice and education scholar at columbia university, a youth mentor, an activist and a future new york state senator. But what got me from there to here wasn't the punishment i faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harshness of our legal system. polished: As I gaze into the mirror today, I behold a justice and education scholar at Columbia University, a youth mentor, an activist, and a future New York State Senator. I see all of that, and I also see a man who spent a quarter of his life in state prison – six years, to be precise, starting as a teenager on Rikers Island for an act that nearly cost a man his life. However, it wasn't the punishment I faced as a teenager in adult prison or the harsh realities of our legal system that ultimately propelled me forward. Instead, it was an extraordinary learning environment in a classroom that opened my eyes to the possibility of redemption and transformation, something I never thought was feasible for me or our justice system as a whole. A few weeks before my release on parole, a counselor encouraged me to enroll in a new college course being offered within the prison walls, and that decision marked the beginning of a transformative journey that would forever alter the trajectory of my life.

Or maybe you're someone who's been oppressed, misinformed, or even a target of misconceptions. Or maybe you're just someone who's simply going through a frustrating airport security check. A study revealed that a staggering 80% of news coverage about Islam and Muslims is negative. Moreover, research shows that many Americans don't know a Muslim personally. Perhaps it's because people don't often engage in conversations with their Uber drivers, who may hold vastly different perspectives. I'm grateful to have the opportunity to meet you, for those who have never had the chance to interact with someone who shares your faith.

polished: In order to establish a comprehensive weather service for water management, it is essential that we collectively demand accountability, as the incentives to fund such a project will not exist without it. My first speaking engagement at a conference was at TED, eight years ago, just after graduating from graduate school. At the time, I was setting the stage for the questions I would be asked for the next decade. Like many of my peers in their early twenties, I was eager to solve the world's problems, particularly the pressing issue of water scarcity. I had a lot to learn. It was an alluring notion, believing that our most pressing water quality challenges persist because they're inherently difficult to detect. Unfortunately, I soon discovered that the issue was more complex than I had initially presumed, and that we needed more than just simpler, faster, and more affordable sensors to address the problem.
